text:
**Simplified Text:**

**Garbage in, garbage out**

Charging families for each bag of rubbish they throw away sounds good for the environment and makes sense for money. But it might not be that simple. In many developed countries, people have regular rubbish collection. Rubbish bags or bins are taken away by a special truck to a dump. This service is usually free. Families pay for it through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that throws away very little. 

However, collecting rubbish is not free. The more rubbish people throw away, the more trucks and workers are needed. This costs local governments money. If rubbish disposal is free, people might throw away too much rubbish. A solution is to make families pay for the rubbish they throw away. This could encourage them to throw away less and recycle more, if local governments help with recycling.

Two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, studied this idea in some American towns. They looked at a town called Charlottesville, Virginia, where families had to pay 80 cents for each bag of rubbish. At first, it seemed like a good idea. The number of bags thrown away went down by 37%. But people found ways to fit more rubbish into each bag instead of buying more tags. 

The total weight of rubbish collected only went down by 14%. In other towns without this fee, the rubbish also went down a little. Some people even dumped their rubbish illegally instead of paying. This illegal dumping might be a big part of the reason for less rubbish collected. 

On a positive note, more people started recycling their rubbish, which is free. But many were already recycling before the fee was introduced. In another study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that charging for rubbish does reduce the amount thrown away, but not by much. A small increase in fees only cuts rubbish by a tiny amount. 

People would need to buy less of everything to really reduce their rubbish. A small fee on rubbish is not likely to change much. Other things, like how much money people have and their education, also matter. In richer towns, people throw away more rubbish and have less time to recycle. 

So, is charging families for rubbish a bad idea? Not really. Free disposal is too cheap. But simple ideas can have complicated results. We need to study these ideas carefully to understand them better.

**Work and Life by Theodore Zeldin**

Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life can change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at your job? Success is not enough anymore. Many people feel their work is not valued. Even famous people can feel unhappy. 

Loving your job used to be enough, but now you should think about how your job affects you. Does it help you grow as a person? If your job makes you boring or too busy to think or be creative, then money and status will not make you happy. 

Zeldin wants to find ways for work to be more fulfilling. Work should not just be about making money. It should help us live better lives and meet new people. But changing work will not end unemployment. Many educated people want jobs that are interesting and helpful.

Even jobs that used to be good, like doctors and architects, can be stressful. Many workers feel unhappy and disconnected from their jobs. In Britain, only 8 out of 100 workers feel their values match their company’s values.

Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He wants to find better ways to earn a living. Many experts focus on making companies richer, but we also need to think about ourselves as people. 

How many of us feel truly alive at work? Many workers feel trapped in their jobs, even if they can leave. For example, hotel workers often work long hours for low pay. Hotels could be more than just places to sleep; they could be places where people from different cultures meet and connect.

Hotel staff often have little chance to use their skills. If hotels listened to their workers' dreams, they could offer more services. But accountants often limit what hotels can do to make money.

Zeldin believes work is about relationships. Many people want to work in a way that gives them freedom. They should be able to choose their jobs and coworkers. Good communication is important, but it is not the same as real conversation. 

Real conversation helps us understand each other better. It creates respect and can change how we see the world. Every good conversation makes the world a little better.

**BROADCASTING: How Technology Changed Communication**

The word 'broadcasting' comes from farming. It means to spread seeds widely. This idea is about growing things in a big way and getting a good harvest. Broadcasting needs a central place to send out information, like a bucket of seeds.

We need to think about why a new technology that sends words and pictures was set up like this. Television is connected to other ways of talking, like the telegraph and telephone. But from the start, it was made to send information to many people at once. This fit well with how society was changing.

In the 1930s, some people tried to make two-way television, like a phone. They wanted to send and receive pictures. Many people in Britain were excited about this and wrote about it in magazines. But big companies took over and made rules that pushed these small inventors out. This was a missed chance for a different kind of television that could have been more equal and open.

In the early 1930s, television was mostly watched in public places, not at home. In Britain and Germany, many people saw TV together in groups. The idea of small, two-way television was not successful. Instead, companies wanted to sell TVs to homes. As people had more money in the 1920s, they wanted TVs for entertainment at home. This is happening all over the world now.

There is a strong link between how society changes and how broadcasting works. As society modernized, power and money became more concentrated. People moved around more, which made them feel more alone compared to earlier times. Centralized broadcasting helped governments share important information with everyone and created a sense of community in the nation.

Broadcasting became the main way to share information through radio and television. However, broadcasting can also help democracy by giving everyone equal access to information. After the World Wars, many countries saw broadcasting as a way for people to participate in society.

Television is changing now, and the word 'broadcasting' might not fit anymore. It may only refer to a specific way of sharing information during a certain time in history.

**Clutter**

Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you have, you still do not feel safe. It is normal to want a home that is good for you. But sometimes, we want too many things. Advertisements make us feel like we need more. They tell us that if we do not have certain things, we are not good enough. 

Next time you walk down the street, try not to look at any ads. They are everywhere: on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, and the internet. They all tell us to buy more things.

**Caves**

Many scientists study caves. They want to know where caves come from, how water moves in them, and what lives in them. Caves are small but interesting parts of nature. They make us curious and want to learn more. 

People have studied caves for a long time, especially in places where caves affect our lives. However, visiting caves can be hard, so many people who study caves are not just scientists. Many are also people who visit caves for fun.

**Weather Watch**

A long time ago, many people watched the weather without any tools. This helped start the study of weather, called meteorology. Since the 17th century, it has become a very technical science. Now, we have satellites and machines that give us weather information quickly. 

Meteorology uses many difficult words that can be hard to understand. But human experience is still very important for making weather forecasts. What people see and feel can help scientists understand the weather better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

I used to think that opera is mainly theatre. Now, I think it is more about music. I worked at a national opera house and learned that music is the most important part. I come from the world of theatre, where words and actors are very important. In theatre, the audience and the actors usually understand each other well.

At music performances, like concerts or operas, many people do not know much about music. Some feel embarrassed about this. Most people admire the skill of the musicians. Even a good musician has worked very hard to be good. Watching great musicians is like watching athletes. We know running for a bus is similar, but athletes are much better.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They do not always understand how hard acting is. They may not be impressed when an actor says a long speech. People often ask actors, "How do you remember all those lines?" This does not mean theatre audiences are less demanding than music audiences. Many people enjoy both.

I think music can learn from theatre. I have seen how a different approach can make concerts better. Live music is very emotional and can connect with the audience. However, music performances often have strict rules, like dress codes, which can make the audience feel less important.

Sometimes, music audiences clap between songs, which can break the mood of the performance. But many people are working to make concerts more welcoming. They want to show that "serious" music is for everyone. I remember a special event called "In Search of Angels." It took place in a cathedral and outside in the town. It was a great experience for the audience, who could also take part.

I wish music could be more exciting and different, like the best theatre. Sometimes, using unusual places for performances can surprise both the performers and the audience. It might not be comfortable, but theatre audiences are brave and follow artists anywhere.

I know that many plays are done in a normal way, like concerts. But I believe we can change how people experience music. I love theatre and music, and I want more people to enjoy them too.

**Sand**  
I think sand is not very nice. It can be useful for making things like glass and concrete, but I don’t like it at the beach. Sand gets in my face and my food. It can also take my things, like car keys and coins. When I am wet, sand sticks to me and is hard to get off. But when I step on a towel or walk on a clean floor, the sand falls off easily. Even after that, I find sand in my shoes and socks for days. I don’t want sand around me.

**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home. They want to keep out bad people. A long time ago, they used ropes to lock doors. Now, we have electronic locks that use cards. But many people still like to use a real key. They feel safer with a key. One company made a new electronic lock, but they also added a real metal key to it.

**Modern Art**  
I was nervous to visit the Tate Modern gallery because I don’t understand modern art. I like some of it, like furry things and bright lights. I wish I knew more about it. The idea is to feel the art, not just to understand it. This gallery helps visitors learn about the art. They have good labels that explain what the art means. Now, I can understand the art better instead of just looking at it.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

Making a movie from a book often means cutting parts of the story. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see things in a new way. When I worked on a movie script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of the dialogue and descriptions from the book and still tell the same story. This does not mean that the original words were not important. It is just different how people pay attention to stories in books and movies.

In a book, we often repeat things to help readers remember characters and their traits. We might say "he said" or "she said" to make it clear who is talking. In movies, we can see the characters and understand who is speaking without these tags. 

**Watching Movies**

When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the story. It takes us away from our everyday lives for a while. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, we are back in the real world. Some people think movies are just for fun and not real art. Many older people, like our parents and teachers, did not see movies as important. They liked to be entertained, but they did not think of movies as art.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios had many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were no clear signs. There were three main entrances, but they all looked the same. It was confusing for new people, but most workers knew how to get around. Because of their hard work, people could enjoy stories of romance and adventure in movies.

**Film-Makers**

Many people want to make movies. There are many books and classes about how to write scripts and make films. Some competitions even give away cameras to help new filmmakers. Robert Rodriguez made a famous movie called El Mariachi for only $7,000. He became a well-known director quickly. 

In the past, filmmakers had to work for a long time before making their first movie. They learned by working as editors or writers. For example, John Huston was 35 when he made his first film. But now, many new filmmakers have to do everything on their own without help from big studios.

In the past, there were many council houses on the west side of the city. These houses were small and not very nice. In summer, there was a bad smell from a factory nearby. In the mornings, a paperboy often looked unhappy as he walked to deliver papers. I don’t remember much from my early life, but I do remember sitting by a window and looking at the houses far away. 

I also remember my mother. She was small and often angry. I didn’t understand why she was angry, so I couldn’t make her feel better. Even as a child, I noticed that she was very lonely. She felt alone even when she was with other people. My mother had strict rules about how to behave. She would clean the house a lot and tell me to "behave proper." I didn’t really understand these rules. They meant not going into other people’s gardens and sitting quietly at the dinner table. 

My mother had some friends, but they were not very cheerful. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who didn’t say much, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. They often talked about their problems, and I felt like I was part of their complaints. It felt heavy, like a big weight on my shoulders, and I wanted to be free from it.

Growing up in West Earlham was very routine. Until I was five, I stayed at home. I remember playing on the floor while my mother sat in a chair. After I turned five, I went to school half a mile away. Some kids had mothers who rode bikes, but my mother let me go with other children. 

I remember summer holidays when I saw a little of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door who told stories, and once I went to a charity event where a kind woman gave out lemonade. My mother didn’t like the charity and thought people only wanted money. She often talked about how bad politicians were. 

My mother was not very kind, but she did care about my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum on the bus. We looked at paintings together. My mother even made a joke once about a painting of a Roman soldier, saying she wouldn’t want to meet him at night. This was a rare moment of fun with her.

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd side of the street. It was getting dark, and the air was wet and cool. I knew this street well. I remembered our neighbors, the Matzes and the Pritchards, and Han Kieffer's grocery store. I also remembered the Krings and the Pottses, where my first friends, all girls, lived. 

The houses on this street were special to me. I remembered the little places in the sidewalk where rainwater flowed from the roofs. I used to ride my roller skates and scooter there. As the street went down, the houses changed. The porches were lower, and the yards were smaller. 

Over the years, things changed. Some wooden parts of the houses were replaced with iron. In Shillington, some homes became stores, and some stores became homes again. I wondered how people lived in these places with the smells of the old shops.

Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. His flat has big doors and brick walls. He did not want his flat to be empty. He wanted to separate his living space from his work space. He used a big piece of plastic to create a hallway and hide his office. He wanted his kitchen to be a place where he could cook for friends or make coffee for clients. 

To make his flat feel warm, he used light wood for the floors and added some old furniture from his parents. 

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. He wrote a famous book called *In Patagonia* in 1977. This book changed travel writing. It was exciting and full of imagination. 

Chatwin sometimes changed facts in his stories to make them better. He believed that traveling could help people discover new histories and adventures.

**Swimming**

One summer day, it rained heavily. I ran across the lawn behind my house and jumped into the pool. I swam back and forth, watching the raindrops splash in the water. The best part was when the rain got stronger, and the sound of birds disappeared. 

During this rainy summer in 1996, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea. I felt tired of swimming in the same place, like a tiger in a cage. 

Many places today have signs and labels. This makes the world feel less real. Walking, cycling, and swimming help us feel free and discover the wild parts of our world. A swimming journey would let me explore the mysterious places that still exist.

**Crying**

Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose. But now, scientists think differently. They say crying is important for social connections, especially between mothers and their children. Many people believe that children cry because they feel helpless.

It is harder to understand why adults cry. The sound of crying is not as important as what we see when someone cries. In early human groups, crying may have helped people trust each other and feel close.

People cry for different reasons. We might cry when we feel sad for someone who is treated unfairly. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to when we hear beautiful music or see a touching speech. We may also cry when we watch a sad movie, and this happens more when we are with other people than when we are alone.

Crying is important for social reasons, and scientists are still studying it.

**The Heat is On**

We all know about global warming. It means the Earth is getting warmer. But how much warmer will it get? And how will it change our lives? Many people have some idea about global warming, but they are not sure what will happen because of it.

A warmer Earth will change the weather everywhere. This will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and live. If these resources change, it is a serious problem.

In the last 100 years, human actions have made the air warmer by adding gases. These gases are connected to the temperature of the Earth. Scientists think that the Earth has warmed by about 6 degrees Celsius in the last century. They believe this is mostly because of pollution from humans.

Scientists use computers to predict what will happen with the climate. These computers use science to look at temperature, pressure, and other factors. But these predictions are not always perfect. They can be slow and expensive to use. 

Most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before. Predictions say that by the year 2100, the average temperature of the Earth will rise by 1 to 3.5 degrees Celsius. The sea level will also rise by 15 to 95 centimeters. This means we will see more extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts.

These changes will affect where plants and animals live. They will also change how we get food and water. Some areas may have big problems, but some changes might be good. For example, in Australia, wheat production has increased because of warmer temperatures.

However, many changes will not be good. Even small changes in climate can make water harder to find. This is a big problem in dry areas. In places like the Mediterranean, there has been less rain in recent years.

Another problem is that glaciers are melting. This will change the ice in the Arctic and affect animals and people living there. The most visible effect of global warming will be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds more water to the oceans. 

Many people live near the coast, so rising sea levels can cause flooding. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could be affected. Many people could lose their homes. Small island countries could disappear completely, which would be very bad for their people and cultures.

Text: 'Mission to Mars

Wanted: a married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars. The couple must be healthy and strong. This will be the first astronauts to go to Mars if Dennis Tito's plan works. He wants to send a spacecraft on 5 January 2018. The spacecraft will go to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars' gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. Saving fuel is very important. The next time Mars and Earth are in the right place is in 2031. 

There is a lot of work to do to make new technology for this mission. If the technology is ready, the spacecraft might go. Even if it does not go, the work will help future missions.'

**AESTHETICS**

Art is important, but it can be hard to understand. Many people think of art as just a building, a book, a painting, or a statue. But art is more than these things. It is about how we feel and experience them.

Sometimes, famous art is seen as perfect. This can make it hard for people to see new ideas about it. When art becomes very famous, it can feel separate from our everyday lives. This makes it hard to understand its true meaning.

To understand art better, we need to connect it to our daily experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our lives. People who study art should help us see this connection.

To really understand art, we might need to forget about it for a moment. We should look at the simple things in life that make us happy. For example, we can enjoy flowers without knowing much about them. But if we want to understand how they grow, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight.

Many people enjoy things like movies, music, and comics, but they do not always think of these as art. When art is only in museums, people look for joy in other places. Some people still think of art as separate from everyday life, even if they don’t like that idea.

When art is connected to our daily lives, we can enjoy it more. The best appreciation of art happens when it is part of our usual experiences.

**Observing Lions**

Lions are big cats that live in groups. They hunt together to catch food. When the sun sets, they move quietly to find their prey. They work as a team to get their next meal. 

Researchers studied lions for many years. They wanted to know why lions hunt together, take care of their young, and scare away other animals with their loud roars. They thought that working together would help lions have more babies. But sometimes, if one lion helps too much, it can lose out. 

Lions are very good at resting and doing nothing. This made it hard for researchers to learn about them. Lions can live for up to 18 years, so it took a long time to find answers.

**Pop Music Review**

Bedrock is a band that made a new album called "New Life." This album changed rock music in a big way. It was different from older music that was serious and loud. Instead, it had happy sounds and funny lyrics. 

The band wrote songs about everyday things like relaxing in the sun. Some songs were sad but beautiful. The album had 16 great songs with no bad ones, which is very impressive.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

When I was a child, I loved stories about wise women called 'The Sibyl.' One story was about an old woman who tried to sell books to a king. She burned some books when he refused to buy them. In the end, he bought the last three books for a lot of money. This story taught me a lesson about life.

I was often alone as a child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they did not want to play with me. My mother told me to do something fun so they would want to join me. It worked, and I learned a good lesson.

When I had to write a travel book, I looked for places that interested me. I don’t like to travel much. I prefer to think about old places and history.

**What Happens to Your Manuscript?**

When you send your book to a publisher, it goes into a big pile of other books. Some young people or part-time workers look at these books. They want to find something special. If they like your book, they will show it to a more important editor.

The editor will decide if your book is good and if it can sell well. They will also think about how popular you might be as an author. Publishers like to meet authors before they decide to publish a book.

**Advertising on Trial**

In the early 1990s, working in advertising was very hard. Many businesses were struggling because of a bad economy. In Britain, in 1991, many people lost their jobs, and many homes were taken away by banks. All businesses were affected, and some lost a lot of money.

People who worked in advertising felt a lot of pressure. They had to help their companies make money, but they had less money to spend on advertising. They were told to do more with less money. At the same time, companies started to understand that they needed to make products that customers wanted, not just what was easy for them to make.

Because of this, advertising became more important. Many companies began to pay more attention to marketing. They learned more about it, and some brands started to market themselves better. This made advertising people more respected, but it also made their jobs harder.

In the 1980s, advertising was doing very well. But in the early 1990s, it was very difficult. Many companies looked closely at how much they were spending on advertising. They wanted to know if it was worth the money. They needed proof that advertising helped them make money.

Companies wanted better advertising strategies and better ideas. They wanted the best people from advertising agencies to work for them. They wanted these people to work very hard to create great ads.

Even though advertising is a tough job, many advertising workers still face the same problems as their clients: how to do more with less money. There are other challenges too. The economy is still bad, and there are new rules about advertising. Also, people’s needs and wants are changing.

Now, it is very important for advertising to work well. Companies want to know which ads are successful. However, help for making better ads is not easy to find. Many companies are too busy to talk about their problems. Those that are doing well often keep their success a secret.

This means that while there are some events to learn about advertising, many books do not help much. They often make it seem like all advertising is great, which is not true. This does not help the people in companies who need to make good advertising.

**The Kitchen**

When I was in university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice. Most of my friends wanted different jobs. Being a chef is hard work. Chefs work long hours, and the job can be stressful and not well paid. But I still wanted to be a chef. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and the social life was not fun. Being a chef seemed like a good change for me. It felt serious and real, unlike my life at school.

My wish to cook was not just because I was a student. I also loved food. I first felt this love when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The food was amazing. I remember my first dish very well. After that meal, I wanted to learn how to cook. I changed my life to prepare for being a chef. My history degree did not matter to me anymore. I learned to cook by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making special meals.

**Diving Lessons**

The swimming teacher was a strong man with tattoos. When I asked him to teach me to dive, he told me to sit on the edge of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward. I practiced this until my lesson was over. The next time, he made me stand up and dive off the edge. He was strict. Every time I came up from the water, he told me what to do: "Don't look down, look up!" "Keep your legs straight!" "Point your toes!"

The next week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high, and I was scared. I stood there, trying to be brave. I waved my arms like he taught me, looked up, and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. But when I hit the water, I fell awkwardly. The teacher looked at me with disappointment. But I was still happy. I felt free, like a bird.

**Travelers**

Some people love to travel. They do things that seem strange to us. They climb high mountains, sail alone on the ocean, and eat bugs if they have to. They can live for a long time in unknown places. Some people think these travelers are odd. They are different from us, and we can ignore them. We are happy in our comfortable lives with warm beds and kitchens.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, but he spends a lot of time on it. He is not the best sailor, but he knows how to sail. He likes to write about his sailing adventures. His small boat has a device that tells him where he is on the ocean. He likes this device, but he also thinks it takes away from the real experience of sailing. He believes that sailors should look at the waves and feel the sea, not just follow a compass. He thinks the ocean used to be full of life, but now it is just a place to sail. Because of this, he has time to watch the waves carefully.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books can help us feel at home in the world. We can see our own lives in the stories of others. In books, we find our thoughts and feelings. Authors use words to describe things we feel but cannot say. They help us understand ourselves better. 

When we read or travel, we see things differently. At first, in a new place, we notice everything. Reading a good book also opens our eyes to things we did not see before. We start to notice the colors in the sky, the changes in a friend’s face, or feelings we did not know we had.

**Author's Note**

These thoughts about travel were published in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I made some small changes to fit the articles, but not much else. I corrected a few mistakes, but I did not change the main ideas. 

Traveling by plane has changed how we see the world. Many people can now visit places without needing special skills, just the price of a ticket. I believe that my fellow travelers are not blind to the world around them. Even a simple postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism words that are used too much, "ecotourism" would win. This word started in the early 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Tour companies realized that many travelers wanted to travel without hurting the places they visited. Now, "ecotourism" can mean anything from living with remote tribes to a short boat trip in Australia. 

Many tours that include nature, wildlife, or adventure are called ecotourism. The original idea was good, but now there are no clear rules. This makes it hard for travelers to know what ecotourism really means.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook about my trip to Transylvania for 50 years. I found it again a few years ago, and it helped me remember that time. In Transylvania, I had a better time than I expected. I stayed in friendly homes for weeks. 

When I stopped for a long time, I did not write in my journal. I thought there was nothing to write about. When I moved on, I was slow to start writing again. I worried that some details were out of order, but I decided it did not matter much. I let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**

Fashion is often thought to be new and only from the 1800s and 1900s. But many people say that fashion has a long history. They think it started in the 1500s and 1600s when trade began to grow. As societies grew and more clothes were made, the meaning of clothing also changed. Now, it is hard to know what a piece of clothing really means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people.

**Writer**

Many stories in the news make it seem like all writers are very successful. But for many writers, life is different. Some writers have other jobs and write in the evenings. Others, like me, do many small jobs. I teach, do workshops, and write articles. I heard about a job writing for a chocolate factory, but I never got that chance. Still, I manage to write my book by working part-time and getting help from friends.

**Sudden Fame**

We started to perform in small places, and soon they were full of fans. We had to use secret doors to avoid being crowded by people. On our days off, it was hard to go outside without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched us, and our managers took care of us. Even though I was shy, I felt a strange confidence. I was not used to this new life.

**Music - The Future Ahead**

Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and in our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, it became easier to listen to music. We have radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, videos, and many new ways to enjoy music. But, fewer people are playing live music, and there are fewer jobs for musicians.

More people can access music now, and this will likely continue. Music is important for many reasons. In our country, no big event is without music. For people, music gives chances for many activities, both formal and informal. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn to play instruments.

I believe people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain, and musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can help children learn better. Research in the USA shows that making music can help with thinking skills. In Europe, group music lessons can help children make friends and focus better in school.

Playing an instrument can also help with other skills. For example, practicing can help with good study habits, and playing in concerts can teach people to be on time and organized. Because of this, there will still be a need for music lessons in the near future.

What about the future? Will music change? I think two things will happen. First, people will listen to many different kinds of music. New styles will mix together. More people of all ages will want to make music together in their communities. If this happens, music teachers will need to change how they teach. They will need to help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This means music lessons will need to change to be relevant for more people.

Teachers will need to inspire and teach students of all ages. They will also need skills to work with different groups and communicate well. This is a big change from how things are done now. It is a chance for music education to show how good it can be.

**Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired. In rich and busy countries, not getting enough sleep and feeling anxious is common. In the USA, 40 million people have trouble sleeping. Some books in Britain talk about people who cannot sleep or places that study sleep.

A sleep expert says, "People need more sleep." When people are busy, they sleep less. They wake up early to avoid traffic. One researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep for 14 hours a night for a month. After three weeks, they slept about 8 hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep.

In Europe, a university in England studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors and how noise at airports disturbs sleep. They ask students to help with their research. Students get paid £5 an hour and change their sleep patterns.

Dr. Louise Reyner helps the students feel better. Some are scared because they wear special equipment on their heads. But the researchers want to learn about sleep, not dreams. In a dark room, they have a driving simulator. The students come in the afternoon when they are usually sleepy. They drive while answering questions. 

One student tries hard not to fall asleep. At first, he sits up straight, but then he starts to blink and nod off. He wakes up suddenly, but the car goes off the road. Dr. Reyner says that drinking coffee can help. Two cups can make someone a safe driver for a while. She suggests energy drinks and gum for people who work at night.

Scientists know some things about sleep. People sleep in cycles. They go through four stages of sleep, from light to deep. When we dream, our body is still, so we do not hurt ourselves. Sleep may help our bodies heal, but scientists are not sure how.

Women usually sleep about half an hour longer than men. Older people need less sleep, but no one knows why. Some researchers say sleep helps us travel through time safely.

In the past, people slept differently. A history professor found that from 1500 to 1850, people went to bed early, woke up after midnight, and then went back to sleep. This time was for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. Poor people enjoyed this quiet time.

By the 17th century, rich people started to sleep less as they used more light. The industrial revolution made people work longer hours. In some places, people still do not have set bedtimes. They sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. In some tribes, noise and the need to watch for danger make it hard to sleep all night. 

It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Poetry recitals are events where people read poems out loud. Many people today feel confused about poetry. There are many types of poetry and different ways to write and share it. Some poets write poems to be read on paper, while others like to perform their poems for an audience.

In the last twenty years, poetry readings have become more popular. Small groups in towns hold these events in homes or community centers. Schools and colleges invite poets to read their work to students. Arts festivals also have poetry readings with famous poets.

For poets who perform, reading their work in front of people is good for them. Their poems are often simple and easy to understand. However, poets who write more complex poems may not be appreciated by new audiences. These poets work hard to create deep and meaningful poetry, but people may not understand it right away.

Listening to poetry readings is not the same as reading poems on paper, but it can be fun and helpful. Hearing poets read their work can show how to emphasize certain words. It is best if the audience has the text in front of them or knows the poems before the reading.

**Oral History**  
Oral history is when historians use people's stories to learn about the past. But this can be tricky. When someone talks about their past, their story can change because of who is listening. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to ask about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers things. The historian also has their own ideas about the past, which can affect the story. So, historians help create new evidence. However, the person telling the story is also not always sure about their memories. Their memories can be mixed with things they have seen or heard from other places, like TV. Sometimes, they remember the past with feelings of happiness or sadness that come from later experiences. These feelings can make their stories seem more real, but they might not be true to the time they are talking about.

**Animal Science**  
Animal science has two main ways to study animals: the physiological way and the whole animal way. Physiologists look at how the body works, like how nerves and muscles help animals behave. The whole animal approach studies how animals act in their natural environment. There are two types of people in this approach: psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists usually work in labs with animals like rats and pigeons. Ethologists study animals in the wild and how they behave naturally. Both types of study are important. Even if we understand how nerves work, we still need to look at how animals behave as a whole. For example, if we want to understand how a bird builds a nest, we cannot just look at its nerve cells. 

**The Social Sciences**  
When students start studying social sciences, they have to learn two things at once. They need to understand the subject and also learn how to study it. This means they must know the facts and also the methods used to find these facts. Social sciences are about people and society, but they are more than just common sense. Each social science looks at different parts of social life and uses special methods and ideas. These ideas help social scientists understand more than what we see every day.

**Classical Architecture**  
In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, and distribution. He did not talk about how useful a building is, but he did explain how to make buildings for different purposes. At first, architecture was seen as an art. Before classical architecture, there were simple homes made of basic materials. These simple homes helped shape the later, more complex buildings. Even though classical temples look fancy, they are really based on simple, single-room homes.

Mui thought it was strange that Chen was not upset. He was excited to make plans with Lily to go for a drive. They chose a Monday next month. It was a quiet day, so they would leave early and come back by noon. This way, they would not lose any customers. Lily would practice driving before that.

Mui bought a road map. She got a discount, and Chen was impressed. But Lily felt a little hurt because she thought Mui did not trust her. Soon, they were at the beach. Lily drove very well. Mui, sitting in the back, had to agree. Chen even clapped for her. 

They drove past the gasworks and the lagoon. Lily parked the car in a quiet street. She was not sure about the parking rules, so she paid to avoid problems. Lily locked the car doors carefully. Chen joked, "No one will want that old car." The sisters did not like this. 

Chen took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. Man Kee was small and warm. He held Chen's sleeve. Chen thought about how he wanted to raise Man Kee. He wanted him to learn about numbers and own many restaurants one day. 

Chen looked at the sea and saw a ship. He used a telescope to see it better. At first, he could not find it, but then he did. It was a small, old ship. Chen told Man Kee, "This ship will take us home one day." He kissed Man Kee's head. 

Lily came over and put her arm around Chen. Chen wanted Man Kee to see the ship, but when he let go of the telescope, it stopped working. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and Lily could only see seagulls flying.

**THE WELL**

I read that if you go deep enough into a hole, you can see the stars when it is clear. I asked you to help me with my idea. You watched me as I pulled up the well bucket. I steadied it on the wall and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I did not think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough. You held the handle while I pushed the bucket off the wall. I fell into the well. I hit my head. 

At first, I saw strange lights. Later, I thought about how cartoon characters see stars when they hit their heads. I felt confused, scared, and then angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say. You called down to me, asking if I was okay. I wanted to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice. I lay still and watched you through my eyelashes. You ran away to get help.

I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself out of the well. I landed on the courtyard stones. I heard loud voices from the castle. I ran away to hide in the shadows. My mother and father came with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming. My father told Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You looked pale and shocked. I was hidden in the shadows, feeling excited. 

Then I saw drops of water on the ground from my wet clothes. I looked back at my father shining a flashlight into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I could not believe no one saw them. My mother was screaming loudly. I felt scared. I had played a trick on you, but now it was serious. I felt bad for not thinking about this before. 

I thought of a plan. I gathered my courage and came out of hiding. I cried out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I fell down on the stones. I sat up, feeling comforted in my mother’s arms. I said I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled through it to get out. I thought I was almost safe until my father came to me. He wanted me to tell my story again. I hesitated. 

He looked at me closely. I said the secret tunnel fell in after me and that the well was dangerous. I looked into my father's eyes and felt scared. He said, "Don't be ridiculous, boy," and walked away. Arthur looked at me with pity. He knew I was lying. I felt sad and ashamed. I realized my father and Arthur saw my actions clearly, and it made me feel even worse.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan is a widow. Her children are now grown up. She is leaving her family home. A big van is outside. It says, "Removers of Distinction." The workers are taking everything from the house. They are wrapping things in newspaper and putting them in boxes. Fred, the removal man, is very careful with the breakable items. 

Susan is leaving a beautiful house. It has four floors and looks over a small harbour. She remembers the years she spent there with her children. When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five, asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" Now, Robert is helping her move. He is making sure she does not forget about the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is very bossy and wants to take care of the piano.

Fred, the removal man, says, "She doesn't look like she's going to cry." Susan asks, "Do people cry?" Fred replies, "Yes, they do. They help us until everything is in the van, and then they cry in an empty room." Susan understands why.

Susan thinks about the piano. She wanted to tell the movers about it, but Robert said it was their job to see it. The piano is in the best room of the house. They will take it last. 

Susan sits on the bottom stair. She remembers the day they moved in. The piano was the first thing they brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers worked hard for two hours to get it in. Robert watched, and Francesca cried, "We can't live without a piano!" They had to find a way to get it inside. Her husband, Peter, helped solve the problem. They took out a window and used a crane to lift the piano inside. The children were very happy.

Now, Susan thinks about how her children are busy and do not come home much. She is also having trouble going up the stairs. She worries about the piano again. Fred asks her if she is okay. She feels nervous. 

Robert and Francesca come to watch. Fred says, "No tears then?" Susan feels like crying. Moving things makes her feel sad. 

Then, the piano comes down the stairs. Fred is careful with it. They take it outside and put it behind the van. Robert laughs first, and soon they are all laughing together. They are happy it is over. As they walk down the path for the last time, Susan only sheds tears of laughter.

**Online Book Reviews for Everyone**

Anyone can write book reviews online. This idea started when the Internet became popular. At first, it was hard for many people to publish their thoughts because they needed some technical skills. But then, Amazon.com, a big online bookstore, made it easy for everyone to write reviews about books.

On Amazon, anyone can write what they think about a book and give it up to five stars. Each book has its own page, and when someone writes a review, it shows up right away. This helps other readers see what people think about the book, not just what the publisher says.

Amazon is very popular, and many people write reviews every day. Because there are so many reviews, Amazon cannot check all of them. They have a team that looks for bad reviews, like those with bad words or personal attacks on the author. But many reviews are still anonymous, so people can write whatever they want.

Some authors write good reviews for their own books. For example, a writer named Lev Grossman was upset about bad reviews for his book. He wrote some good reviews under a fake name to make his book look better. But later, he told everyone what he did, and Amazon removed his fake reviews.

Authors can also write comments about their books on Amazon. They can say nice things and even give their email addresses for readers to contact them. However, Amazon does not always check if the comments are really from the authors.

Sometimes, readers get very angry about a book. For example, when a book called "We've Got Spirit" was published, some people who were mentioned in it wrote bad reviews. Many of these reviews disappeared after a few days. But Amazon liked that so many people were writing and reading reviews because it was good for business.

Most reviews on Amazon are serious. They help other readers decide if a book is good to buy. A famous writer, George Orwell, once said that writing too many reviews can be hard. But now, with everyone able to write reviews, it is a good thing for readers.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, people often think that artists must be different from others. We say that art should be unique and surprising. We like to admire artists whose work was not appreciated in the past. But when we see new art today, we sometimes think it is too strange and not real art. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be new and confusing. We forget that today’s art has old ideas and methods.

In the past, people asked artists to create art for special reasons. Art was a part of everyday life. Now, artists work alone, and we can get upset if they try to connect with us.

Then, the artist asks someone to make a canvas and write the text on it in simple black letters. My question is: is this finished piece a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London, there is a rule for painters: once you find a style that sells, you should stick to it. People expect artists to keep making the same type of art. If they try something new, people may not like it. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, can change their style and still be successful. Eric Rimmington is another artist trying something new. He is moving from still life paintings to paintings about the London Underground. He finds the underground world interesting. His new show, called Underground Encounters, has 40 paintings and drawings that show the magic of this hidden world.

**A Short Story**

I have come to this island with some books. I do not know why I say "escape." The villagers joke that only a sick person would come to such a lonely place. I am here to heal myself. I am alone except for an old woman who comes from the village to clean my house. I feel neither happy nor sad; I feel like I am floating in my memories.

I talked about how art can seem useless, but it also brings comfort. Art helps us see the world in a new way. Our daily lives can hide the true meaning of things. For artists, art helps us deal with our pain and find joy. It allows us to face our lives and use our imagination. Otherwise, why would we hurt each other?

**Family Business**

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father had just picked me and my big suitcase from my fancy girls' school. He also went to Parent's Day, where I got a prize for Latin and another prize for my exams. He talked a lot with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, but I already knew what he was thinking. My dad usually talks a lot, but now he was quiet. "You can't fool me. You will do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I replied. "Mightn't that be useful?" 

"I also heard," he continued, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My dad knew a lot about lawyers. 

"I just said that," I said. "I didn't know what else to say!" 

"And I heard you have the right personality. You can understand things quickly, you talk well, and you like to perform," he said. 

"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV." 

"Anyway," he said, "I feel like you will not want to join the family business. You will go to Oxford University, and after that, I don't think you will want to do it." 

I felt trapped by what my family wanted. I saw many jobs I could do, and I wanted to explore them. But I didn't want to upset my dad. I was not as scared of him as my brother Maurice was, but I still found him strong. 

"It's too soon to know," I said quietly. 

"I tell you, you will not want to join us," my dad said. "It's a pity because you have the skills." 

"There's still Maurice," I said, feeling sad. My dad laughed. We both knew Maurice did not like the business. 

"Anyway," I said, "you could use me as a consultant." My mother was not around to help us. She died when I was young, and my dad raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger than me, and I took care of him. I loved him. 

Because the business was successful, we lived well. We had a big house in London, nice schools, good clothes, and fun events. My dad knew many important people, and our house was always busy with interesting talks. 

"I tell you what," my dad said. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford. Then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some money and help me." 

"OK," I said, happy to avoid making big choices right now. I didn't want to see my dad sad if I disagreed with him. 

So, I helped out during my last term at school and during breaks from university. I became a smart student with my own small house, a nice car, and good clothes. I even had a special black dress for my final exams. 

In my last term, my dad came to see me. He took me to a village for a meal and a talk. My teacher said I would get a First Class degree in Law. I felt ready and confident. 

Then my dad told me he needed me to do one last important job for the family business. He said it was the most important job ever, and it would be worth it for me. 

"But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon. I need to focus on that. It's really important!" 

I could see my dad did not understand how important my exams were. He would think I was being unkind if I said no. As he talked about the job, I saw how focused and strong he was. He was very good at his work, and I admired that. It made my own plans feel less important. 

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello bought a house in Pembroke Square with his wife, Lois. After a year, he thought it was a mistake. They needed to save money, but at first, buying the house seemed like a good idea. Simon had many successful cases at work, and Lois returned to her job after having twins. She earned a good salary, and she wanted to move to a bigger place because their flat was too small for their family.

Lois wanted a nice home because she thought it was important for their status. She decided that one of them should take public transport to save money, and Simon had to do it because Lois's job was far away. The train rides were crowded, and Simon often felt unhappy and jealous.

He remembered his grandfather's house, where he felt safe and cared for. His grandmother always took care of the family. But things were different now. Lois wanted her career to be as important as Simon's. They needed both of their salaries to pay for the house and their lifestyle.

One day, a woman named Venetia came to their office. She was very angry about something. Simon wished he had left his room earlier to avoid her. Venetia accused him of not doing the right thing in a past case. She said a man named Brian Cartwright claimed Simon knew he had bribed jurors but did nothing about it. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty and nervous.

He wanted to explain that he didn't believe Cartwright, but instead, he lied. He saw the disbelief in Venetia's eyes and felt ashamed. He wondered why she was so angry and if she had the right to judge him. He was scared that if people heard the rumors, it could ruin his career.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be alone. I wanted to be around people who did not care about broken houses or messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon recognize me. The beautiful roses from next door remind me that gardens can be nice. I usually stay inside, but tonight I watch the birds flying. I cut some plants to make space for a chair, and my arms feel itchy from the work. 

It is a small garden in London, where plants have to grow tall to live. My neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window. She is a writer, and I sometimes help her with her work. She has a new story, and I have a copy. "How is your work going?" I ask her. She complains about her job. "I have something to drink in the fridge. I will bring it down," she says. I do not want her in the garden, and I see it looks messy. Jaz knocks on my door. 

She sits in the garden and talks about her life. "What are your plans for the holidays?" she asks. I feel worried about the empty days ahead. I think about going to the park and feeling lonely. "I am going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?" I ask. "Of course," Jaz replies. "Where will you stay?" she asks. "I will stay with my friend Ruby," I say, but it is not true. 

Jaz asks about her story, "The Cruelty of Red Vans." I like the title. I think red vans can be cruel because they bring gifts to other people. I decide to give Jaz some advice. "Try writing about nice people," I say. She does not like my advice. "I keep a journal and write something good every day," I tell her. She laughs at me. 

When we go inside, I feel calm in my kitchen. But then I remember my old teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who once winked at us and said, "I've had my moments." We all laughed.

**Heritage**

Heritage means the things we get from our past. It helps people feel connected to their history. We often know about our grandparents and their stories. Learning about our past helps us understand our future. Heritage is important because it gives us a sense of belonging. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit our culture from our families. Some parts of our heritage may not be good, but it is still a part of us. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our happiness. It includes our customs and the things we make. 

In the past, we learned about our history through stories from our ancestors. But now, many of these stories are lost. We can learn about our past from old buildings and places. It is important to take care of these places to remember our ancestors.

**The Fens**

I wrote a book called *Waterland*. In this book, I wrote about a place in England called the Fens. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and quiet. But when I learned more, I found out that the Fens are interesting and different. Many people in England think the Fens feel strange, even though they are part of England. The Fens are both empty and full, and they are both farmed and wild. 

I have not visited some places in the Fens, but I like to imagine what they are like. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a way of thinking.

**Museums**

Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, they just put things in glass cases with long labels. Now, museums should be more interesting and fun. They can use different ways to show their items and make people feel something. 

Museums should help everyone enjoy their collections. For example, they can give boxes of objects to teachers or help elderly people who forget things. Museums show real items from history, not copies. This is what makes them special. Museums that create exciting displays and programs will attract more visitors who want to see real history.

**Architecture and Environment**

Wanting to keep things safe is not new. But now, changes in our towns happen very fast. This can make some people want to protect old things. People who lived through big events, like wars, may want to keep things stable. If we need to preserve things, planners should think about this. Change is not bad if we learn to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in our society, like how many people live there and what they need.

**Einstein**

If you ask people to name a scientist, many will say Albert Einstein. His picture is used to sell things like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did. They know he made important ideas called "relativity." These ideas are famous but hard to understand. Einstein helped change how we think about science in the 20th century. Scientists wanted to understand the universe better by looking at how things work together. Einstein looked at basic ideas like time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, Isaac Newton said that stars and planets moved in a fixed way. Einstein said that time and space are not fixed; they can change.

**Young Readers**

When we were kids, my sister Lydia and I did not like books that won prizes. We thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this and would tell us to read better books. Our father would give us money for each chapter we read. He also gave us some special books for Christmas and birthdays. He wrote on them, "This Book is NOT Literature." We thought many of his books were for boys, but he did help us read some good stories and poems.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the start of human language is a secret and amazing thing. Many people have strange ideas about how language began. Charles Caller said in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. People in the past made sounds when they were in danger, and some words today still show this, like "malaria" meaning "fever" and "mors" in Latin meaning "death." Many people thought these ideas were silly, but now, studying how language started is important. Language likely began in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech to be friendly and to help with power struggles. Sharing information was not the main reason for language, which is different from what philosopher John Locke said.

**Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode talks about writing reviews. Most reviews are short and do not last long. They have deadlines and must be a certain length. When they are published, they are only in the newspaper for a short time, like a day or a week.

People often think that writing reviews is not important. They believe that writers only do it for money or because they cannot work on their main books all day. But writing reviews is a skilled job. It is different to write a short review of 600 or 800 words than to write a longer one of 6,000 or 8,000 words. 

A reviewer must think about who will read the review. Some readers just want a quick look, while others want to read a serious article. A good reviewer needs to know a lot about different topics and write in a way that is easy to understand.

Many reviewers also write other things, not just reviews. For example, the American writer John Updike writes novels but also writes reviews. He collects all his reviews into books, even if they are short.

Some people think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews are not very important. But if they believe their best writing is in reviews, they should be proud of it. 

I have mostly worked in academics, and my serious books are for professors. In English-speaking countries, it is common for the same people to write reviews and study literature. 

In the past, some academics did not like professors who wrote reviews. But now, it is more accepted. There are many reviews today, so many people can write them. This is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. 

Writing reviews helps professors remember to explain things clearly to everyone, not just to other professors. They should not use difficult words when talking to smart readers who are not professors. 

In conclusion, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a side job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph opened the door to his flat. It was dark and quiet inside. He felt a small happiness to be home, even after three years. When he first bought the flat, he was always excited to come back. He wondered what the flat had been doing while he was away. It felt like a special place just for him. 

Sometimes, he worried about things like break-ins or leaks, but his flat was always there, waiting for him. It looked different depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to think of it as part of himself. He wanted to change it, but it stayed the same. 

There were always letters by the door and a blinking answering machine when he got home. He was happy that nothing was broken in his flat. From his office, he often looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After a long day at work, he wanted to be alone, but he also felt lonely. 

He would read or listen to music at night, but he started to wonder why he did these things. He felt lost and confused. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and more sure of himself. After university, he tried to make a plan for his life, but he just wanted to get by. 

He applied for jobs that his friends talked about. He felt tired and followed them, hoping to find happiness. He went to one job interview and was happy to talk with Neil, the boss. Neil offered him the job right away, saying he was the only graduate who applied. Ralph took this as a compliment.

**How to Be Presentation Perfect**

I am not good at making presentations, but as a manager, I have to present to my team and important people. How can I get better and feel more confident?

You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company. Many managers need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you say. Show your passion and enthusiasm. 

This means you need to prepare well. Think about your ideas and ask your colleagues what hard questions the audience might ask. You should also start with something everyone can relate to and then lead to your main point.

Some activities take time. You cannot hurry them. If you are late for a meeting, you can rush. But if you are too quick with mayonnaise, it will not be good. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, it will get worse. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things happen very fast, but others take a long time. 

We can get better at some things, like solving puzzles. But some things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they will not work well. For example, you cannot sleep well in a short time. We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds.

There are three speeds of thinking. The first is very fast. Sometimes we need to react quickly. For example, if you fall off a bike, your body knows what to do before you think about it. This fast reaction is called our "wits."

The second speed is thinking. This is when we solve problems and make decisions. A mechanic fixing a car or a student doing homework is using this kind of thinking. We call this "intellect." People who are good at this are often called "clever."

The third speed is slower. This is when we think in a relaxed way. We might daydream or think about things without a clear goal. For example, sitting by the sea and listening to the waves is a different way of thinking. This slow thinking is also important. 

Taking time to think slowly is good for us. Sometimes, we need to think slowly to understand complicated problems. If we are not sure what to do, it is better to sit and think than to rush. This slow thinking can help us be creative and wise. 

Poets and philosophers know that slow thinking is important. Scientists are now studying how our minds work slowly. They find that our minds can solve problems and understand things better when we give them time.

Soon, we may see many discoveries about Lake Vostok.
