**NATURAL TALENTS**

Humans and chimpanzees have a lot in common. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means that the differences between us and animals are very small and new. 

Many studies show that animals can do things we thought only humans could do. For example, chimpanzees use sticks to eat and to fight. Sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have simple sounds to warn each other about danger, like leopards and snakes. 

So, what makes human art special? For a long time, our ancestors did not make art. The first art we know about is from about 35,000 years ago. This art includes cave paintings, statues, and musical instruments. 

Some people say human art is different because:

1. Human art is not made to help us survive. It is made for enjoyment. Animals make sounds to find mates or protect their homes. This is important for their survival.
   
2. Human art is made for beauty. We do not know if animals enjoy their songs. They sing mostly during mating season, so they might not sing just for fun.

3. Human art is learned. Each culture has its own style of art. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. Animals, like birds, are born knowing how to sing their songs. 

There are also some interesting examples of animal art. Two chimpanzees, Congo and Betsy, made many paintings. They painted for fun, not to communicate with other chimps. Their art was shown in a gallery in London, and many people bought their paintings. 

This shows that the line between human art and animal behavior is not so clear. Both humans and animals can create art for their own enjoyment.

**A Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is a very big and dangerous place. Charles Blackmore crossed this desert and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left in the world. In the past, stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes looking into the distance. Now, we do not see these heroes in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Charles Blackmore led a group to cross the Taklamakan Desert. The name means "once you enter, you never come out," and local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of this amazing journey while at home with his family. His team had four British people, one American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for everyone.

They set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He wanted to have fun and find out who he really was. His wife, Tina, was worried he might not come back because no one had ever crossed that route before. It took them 59 days to go from west to east, and the desert was nice to them.

In his story, Charles talks about the hard times they faced: sickness, extreme heat and cold, and not enough water. They lost some of their water supply. But he said, "When we were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some." They did not have the famous sandstorms or the freezing cold that could have stopped them. But they still had many problems. The sand got into everything, and climbing the high dunes was very hard for them and the camels.

Charles said, "What pushed me to keep going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. We were all alone in the sandhills." He was scared about his strength to finish the trip. On the first day, he felt very hot and thought, "We have to do this now!" He was scared.

After walking 1,000 kilometers, they could not stop. They had gone through so much. They were thin but strong. Charles felt fit and could walk easily. In the middle of the book, he wrote about lying in the desert and looking at the full moon, thinking about his family. He felt he needed to find peace inside himself. He said, "I feel prouder of this trip than anything else I have done. But my family and our happiness are more important."

Did Charles find peace? He said, "I want the challenge and the open spaces. We felt good about our purpose. Now, it is hard for me to be part of normal life."

**Text: Life Without Gadgets**

Susan Harr is trying to live without technology. Many people love their gadgets because they make life easier. But Susan thinks that we depend too much on them. She had a problem with her computer and had to pay a lot of money to fix it. This made her think that gadgets can be more trouble than they are worth.

Susan started to stop using some of her gadgets. She wonders if technology really gives us more time. Sometimes, it seems like we just buy more gadgets instead. When her computer made strange noises, she put it outside. Now, she can take her time doing things by hand.

Susan likes to sew. She used to have a sewing machine, but now she sews by hand. She finds it nice to sit and sew while listening to the radio or talking to family. She enjoys this more than watching TV. 

Sewing by hand is relaxing for Susan. She feels happy when she sees her work getting better. She also likes to wash dishes by hand and daydream while doing it. 

Now, Susan looks around her house and thinks about what she really needs. She wonders if she needs a freezer, a microwave, or even electric lights. She thinks life can be good without so many gadgets.

Text: 'Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker. He makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles seems to be a busy man. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He looks very busy. The workshop has many pieces of furniture and wood in different colors. 

Charles has been a cabinet-maker for ten years. He is well-known for his work. Many people want to buy his furniture, so he has many orders. He does not advertise himself, but people know he makes good cupboards, tables, and bookcases. 

It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is hard to find a good one. Charles says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now." He is not happy with some modern furniture. He thinks some furniture-makers do not make good quality furniture. He wants to make perfect furniture, and this is why he is successful. 

Charles is confident in his skills. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work is for private people. Some clients come back to him many times. He enjoys making furniture for their whole house. 

However, he finds it hard when clients do not know what they want. He likes clients who are clear about their needs. Charles is happy with his work, but he also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people far better than me." 

He does not like when craftsmen take a long time to make one piece of furniture. He thinks furniture should be useful, not just a fashion statement. Charles is confident, but he is also humble. He says, "After all, I am only making furniture," as I leave.'

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People sleep for about one-third of their lives. Sleep is very important, but we do not know exactly why. Scientists have three main ideas about why we sleep.

The first idea is that sleep helps our bodies stay healthy. When we sleep, our bodies fix any damage from the day and get ready for the next day.

The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us remember things we learned during the day. Without sleep, it is hard to learn new things.

The third idea is about energy. This idea says we need sleep to recharge our energy. When we sleep, we get ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, some people like to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to the newspaper about many topics.

Being eccentric shows our uniqueness. Inside us, there are two forces. One is called individualism, which means being yourself. The other is conformity, which means following what others do. Most of the time, we want to fit in and be liked by others. This desire is stronger than wanting to be different.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs and hold meetings to talk about what they like or their problems. They want to be with others who understand them, even if others think they are strange. Being in a group can make us feel safe.

We all feel a struggle between being ourselves and fitting in. Even when we follow the crowd, we may not like it. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is different. 

Anyone can choose to be more individual. Some people become very successful by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you know what you want to do, go for it and don’t give up." 

However, being different just to get attention is not true eccentricity. If a pop star wears strange clothes just to be noticed, that is not eccentric. But if they keep being different for a long time, they may become eccentric. 

True eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, no matter what others think.

**Natural Books**

We asked four nature experts to tell us about their favorite wildlife books.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy to choose the author. I am an environmental journalist, and I have met many important people in this field. One of them is Barbara Ward. She is a small, thin woman, but she is very important for environmental issues in Europe. She has combined her experiences into her own ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand many things. Choosing her book was harder. I could have picked "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think her most important book is "The Home of Man." This book talks about the fast growth of cities and important themes in her life. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books, but none are as good as this one.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of seagulls and remember the smell of the sun. This book explains animal communication very well, with words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a group of seagulls, you will see how they work together. Niko Tinbergen was a great scientist who wanted to share his ideas with everyone. He worked with a talented artist, Eric Ennion, to make this book interesting for all nature lovers. Eric's paintings show how birds act, like when one bird is aggressive and another is calm. This is the work of a true nature expert.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell has changed my life the most. It helped me find a wonderful husband and a great job in conservation. This book made me love the natural world. I was in Madagascar studying animal sounds when I first read it. I had many problems, but when I read this book, I felt happy again. It shows animals and people together in a beautiful world. Some people think humans are bad for nature, but I remember Gerald as a boy, seeing all living things as a family. We need to understand this idea.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library when it was first published in 1966. I loved it right away, especially the beautiful pictures of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and learned to identify birds during my holidays. But "The Shell Bird Book" had so much more. It had amazing pictures, stories about bird migration, and even a chapter about birds in music and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature more. It showed me that my feelings about nature are just as important as scientific facts. Since I was better at art than math, I felt like I could explore nature in my own way.

**DO REVIEWS HELP SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in the newspaper. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or displays in shops. Authors feel sad when there are no reviews. Publishers are also unhappy with bad reviews, but they think any review is good because it gets people talking about the book. A review that matches what the publisher thinks is the best.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, especially in a good way. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help people know about the book and the author. A good review from a trusted person can help sell more books.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we need reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they show the reader that the review is honest. Good reviews can help a book sell well, but they need help from other things like recommendations from friends and good marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I am not sure how publishing and reviewing work together in Britain. In the United States, one review can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops do not always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews still sell very well. It is hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction books let reviewers talk more about the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. The name of the reviewer used to matter a lot, but now, sometimes a surprising reviewer or a clever review can make people want to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

Making weathervanes is an old skill. It started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith makes weathervanes in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes them by hand. 

Graham creates special designs for his customers. He says, "This way, I can make a unique gift." Many of his customers are women who want to buy gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows what their husbands like.

Most weathervanes are shaped like cockerels, but Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. Graham saw that he could make many different designs. 

He decided to start a weathervane business. Before this, he worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed jobs. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of the children and build his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this is exciting."

Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays attention to details and always asks the customer if they like the design before he starts cutting. He also keeps some traditional designs because people like them too. 

Graham believes people enjoy handmade items. They want something different. He does not want to grow his business too much because he likes it as a small craft. He says, "People love unique items, and I feel good when I see a simple shape become something special."

For many years, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add something special to their homes. This helps crafts like Graham's business.

Graham is busy making weathervanes for customers all over the world. People from America and Denmark are especially interested. He says the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was a very popular book. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. He talks about his ideas and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was not doing well. A film he was working on did not happen. He was sad and worried because he had not made money for two years. He needed money to pay the bank. A smart person would have found a job, but Nicholas did something different. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.

Nicholas had an idea for the story from a farrier he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became very angry. The owners were worried until they heard about a gypsy who could talk to the horse and help it. These people are called "horse whisperers." Nicholas liked this idea and wanted to write a movie about it. But after the film project failed, he decided to write a book instead.

During the spring, he drove around the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses. He felt alone and worried about his life. He had tried to be a filmmaker for ten years, but now he was in debt and worried about his family.

By the end of August, he had written half of the book. The bank was pressuring him for money, so he showed his work to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was good and that Nicholas might get $30,000 for it. Nicholas needed this money to pay off some debt. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had more to write.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the book to seven publishers. Soon, his agent called to say that they had turned down an offer of $75,000. Nicholas was surprised. But then, within a week, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. This was a record for a first novel.

Nicholas could not believe it. He had not even sent the book to New York, but soon big movie studios wanted to make a film from it. His agent in the UK worked with an agent in the US, and they got an offer of $3 million for the movie rights. Nicholas was amazed when he heard this.

One night in October, four famous filmmakers called him to ask for the rights to his unfinished novel. Nicholas decided not to write the movie script himself. He wanted to keep his freedom and not become just an employee. He was happy with how things were going and thought it was a good idea to write another novel.

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer is trying to come back to chess. He is not young anymore. Chess is now a game for young players. After 20 years away, Bobby Fischer is playing chess again. He is playing against Boris Spassky, his old rival. Bobby won the first game, and it was very good. But he is now 49 years old, and he has not played much. Boris Spassky is also older.

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Bobby Fischer made chess popular, and now it is more professional. Today, players want to win more than anything else. In chess, a player needs to be strong and calm, not just smart. The game is very intense. Players have a chess clock to keep time. If they do not make their moves in time, they lose.

Now, games can be longer, and players often do not take breaks. This makes it harder for older players. In the last 30 years, new world champions have been younger than the last ones. Most of the top ten players are under 30 years old.

Today, players also prepare a lot before matches. They use computers to study many chess games. A small computer can hold one million games. Players have teams to help them find weaknesses in their opponents. The start of a game is very important, and being well-prepared can help a lot.

There are more great chess players now than ever before. Many grandmasters play for small prizes around the world. A game can last up to eight hours. Players must stay focused, or they can lose. The chess clock makes it even more stressful. At the end of a game, players often rush to make their moves.

Losing is very hard for top players. Winning feels great, but one win is not enough. Players must be ready to play again the next day. Chess tournaments can last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches can be even harder. One match in 1984 had to stop because the players were too tired.

Can Bobby Fischer come back and win? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his long break from chess surprising. If he is back for the money, he will earn a lot. But if he wants to prove he is the best, it could be very hard for him.

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, like poets and pop stars, who are becoming famous.

**A** Nick Grosso is a man in his 30s. He has written three plays that people like. Now, he is making his first play, called Peaches, into a movie. He says, "It is low budget, but I don’t know how low. It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but before he wrote Peaches, he had never seen or read a play. He says, "When I wrote the play, I did not think it would be performed. It is set in a car. I would not do that now because I know it is hard." He left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He wanted to write for actors because he liked to hear his writing. He says, "I was happy to be with people who think like me. It was the first time I enjoyed school."

**B** Simon Pegg is 28 years old. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a comedy show for TV and just finished a tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. He practiced comedy in clubs while at university. He says, "University was very theoretical. I realized I did not want to be a serious actor. I like comedy more. People think comedy is very hard, but it is not. If you have courage and good ideas, it is great to make people laugh." He has worked with Funny Business, but his best work is with Steve Coogan. Simon says, "He saw my show, and I was a big fan of his."

**C** Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous when he danced in the show The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. People liked him a lot. He says, "It has been great for me. Now, I can choose what I want to do." Ciaran has just finished school, but he has acted for a long time. His mother encouraged him to act. He says, "I used acting to avoid homework. But then I wanted to do it seriously because I liked it." Now, he waits for good things to happen, but he thinks about fame. He says, "When you are 18, you think you will love the photos and interviews, but you learn it is not why you act. It is about respect for good work."

**D** Neil Taylor is 25 years old and is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They just signed a deal to make three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very popular when their song, Chimera, comes out. Neil says, "The record company wants big sales, but I just want two people to buy it." Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for many years. He says, "I was tired after doing many small gigs. I was about to give up when I met Rick, who helped me start Matrix." 

**E** Stephen Richards is 27 years old. He is a poet and writer. He has won many awards. He is well-known in poetry and has been reading his work for six years. His first novel, Hidden, will come out in March. He says, "It is a story about obsessive love. I could not write it as a poem." Stephen loved writing in school but did not like school later. He did not go to university at first but changed his mind after working at a theatre. He published his first book, a children's book, in 1992. He says, "My parents thought I would be a reader, not a writer." Now, he is brave to write novels. He says, "Poetry has rules, but novels can be any length. I want to make sure my writing is good."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student. She thinks she looks good in jeans, but she does not wear them often. She is looking for the right man but worries that her knees are not nice enough. Isabel has hope, and this helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a fun and lively way, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story is about a local radio station in America. A smart boy named Francis works for WLT Radio. The station was started by two men, Roy and Ray, to help their sandwich shop. Soon, the radio plays many different kinds of shows with singers and speakers. The author uses humor to show life in a small town and takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old cars and radios.

C. In this story, a man named Richard talks to his wife’s ex-husband. Richard falls in love with a Russian poetess. She writes bad poetry and wants Richard to help her brother, who is in jail. The author tells this story in a funny and clever way, making it enjoyable to read.

D. In London in the 1960s, two sets of best friends meet. One friend, James, is starting a newspaper with Richard. This is important because a woman they both loved was killed years ago. The story has murder, love, and jealousy. It is a long book where you can really get to know the characters.

E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming a strange bachelor. The story shows the special bond he has with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four writers talk about international volunteer work.

A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money to the local community, it could pay for more help than one person can give. This is especially true for young people who take a gap year. They often do not have special skills or experience. Many studies ask if these young people want to help others or if they just want to make their own careers better. However, these projects can help people learn to care for others in their future jobs.

B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can help solve problems and create connections between people from different countries. When this happens, both the volunteers and the local communities can benefit. But if only rich people can volunteer, it may help them more than the communities they visit. These volunteers may gain experience, but it does not help the people who need it most.

C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to feel good about themselves. It can also be a way to help communities with skills and knowledge. At its best, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the communities. It can also make people aware of problems like poverty and injustice.

D. Volunteer tourism is part of a trend where people want to help others. This can seem good, especially when people do not trust big governments or businesses. But it can also ignore the need for real change in poor communities. Volunteering can be a good thing, but when it is only seen as a way to help without understanding the bigger problems, it can be a problem itself.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports

Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need an alarm to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?

I, Tom Granger (an inventor), and Paul Bridges (a broadcaster) tested five clock radios. One model has a 'dual alarm function.' This means you can set two different wake-up times. One for work days and one for weekends. But who really needs that? This model costs about the same as another one we tested. It has a cassette player, so you can listen to your own music and wake up without news. We all liked the radio quality, but it is very big, like a rugby ball. Paul said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also likes to book a wake-up call, just in case the alarm does not work.

This model was voted the best. Paul said he loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with nice grey numbers on a green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. But the buttons felt nice to touch, and I accidentally pressed them too much. The clock has a backup battery, so it does not reset if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. However, setting it up was hard, but we felt good when we finally did it.

Tom did not like one model with a built-in lamp. He said it was hard to use. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work. The light was not good for reading; it only shines on the clock. Paul thought the lamp idea was funny, but he said the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm, and I wanted to throw it away.

Another model is very popular. It is bright and colorful, which Tom and I liked. Tom said he would choose this one because it stands out. This model was easy to set up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can be 20 minutes early or late. Paul laughed at this and said it was very annoying.

The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to set up. With modern buttons, you are not sure if you pressed them right. We thought the tuning was not great, but the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. You can find hedgehogs in many places in the world, but they do not live in America or Australia. When a hedgehog is in danger, it can roll into a tight ball. The spines stick out to protect it. Some hedgehogs live in the desert. They have fewer spines and may try to run away instead of rolling up.

Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They like to sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all of them do. Some hedgehogs stay awake all year if the weather is good.

**Great Sportswomen Winning**

It is hard to be good at any sport, especially for women. They have to work very hard. They train a lot and do not have much time for a normal life. They make sacrifices. But they are winning and breaking records. Here are some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.

A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love to ski and jump in the air. It can be scary sometimes. We train for ten months each year, so I do not see my friends much. But I chose this life. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete together and are treated the same."

B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else! I earn good money as a professional cyclist. I train for at least four hours every day. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."

C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because few schools have rowing teams. Most girls start when they are older, which makes it harder to compete. But I love rowing and being fit. It is also fun to be with friends."

D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I did not know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very hard. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep. I got a record, but it was painful. Some people think women cannot do this, so they do not want to sponsor us."

E. **Lisa, 26, Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they do not talk to me. Being a woman in racing is hard. I have to be very competitive. Women have been racing for a long time, and now more women are joining."

"I wake up at 5:30 AM to swim three times a week. I also cycle and run in the evenings. Sometimes I feel tired at work! Racing is hard, but I feel happy when I am fit. Men and women usually race together, but the news talks more about the men's races. We are working to make things better for women in sports."

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso. He was 78 years old and a famous artist. Even from far away, you could see it was him. I was 18 years old and traveling in a broken van around Europe and Morocco. I ran out of money and found a job painting boats. I spent a lot of time drawing and had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso usually stayed at home, so I was surprised to see him at a restaurant with his wife and friends. I was nervous, but I asked him for his signature. He smiled and wrote his name on my paper. Then he drew some fun lines on it too. I was very happy and thanked him. We tried to talk, but his English was not good, and my French was not good either. An American woman helped us talk. She called him "the Maestro."

I told Picasso that I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend the signature. He said, "Is that all? Go back and talk to him more!" So, I took my sketchbook and went back to Picasso's table.

I didn’t ask him if I could draw his portrait because I was afraid he would say no. Instead, I just started to draw. When Picasso saw me, he made funny faces to distract me. He rolled his eyes and stuck out his tongue. It was hard to draw him, but I wanted to try. After a while, he stopped being silly and let me draw him quietly.

I looked at him closely. He looked strong and young for his age. His eyes were bright and full of life. Even though he was with friends, he seemed to be in his own world. The American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing. I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But he wanted to see it anyway. When I showed it to him, he smiled and nodded.

Then, to my surprise, he took my crayon and drew a picture of me. He did it very quickly and made it look fun. I looked different in his drawing, like a character from a story. I thanked him and asked if he could sign it. The American woman said he said I already had his signature. 

I felt lucky to meet Picasso and to have his attention. It was a special day for me.

**Shopping Tricks**

Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that stores use to make you spend more money.

A. **Fresh and Nice**  
Stores know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance. Some stores even have bakeries that smell like fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, make people think of fresh food.

B. **Where Things Are**  
The place where products are in the store is very important. Stores use computers to find out where people look for items. They put popular items at eye level so people can see them easily. Special offers are often in big bins to attract buyers.

C. **Moving Around the Store**  
Stores may put cheap items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers see other tempting items on the way. Stores also put popular products far away, hoping customers will look for them and see other things to buy.

D. **Less is More**  
Some stores, like Next, show their clothes in a nice way. They do not put many clothes on the shelves. This makes the clothes look special, even if they are made in large amounts.

E. **Total Price Matters**  
People care more about the total price of their shopping than the price of each item. Stores mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. Some stores sell cheap items to bring people in, even if they lose money on them.

F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, people often buy fewer items and notice prices more. For example, a blouse priced at £14.99 seems cheaper than one at £15. 

G. **Lighting**  
Stores think a lot about lighting. Chain stores use lights that look like natural sunlight so customers can see colors well. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh food look better.

H. **Paths in the Store**  
Many stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. They create paths that lead to sales areas. Some stores use nice carpets to make shoppers feel welcome.

I. **Promotions**  
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of tasty food. In some places, shopping carts have screens that show ads for products while you shop. This is to make you want to buy more things.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington is a famous mountaineer. He climbed Mount Everest in 1985. He has also climbed in Britain and the Alps. He has written many books, like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way."

Robin Knox-Johnston started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his boat called Sunhaili. He also set a record for sailing from New York to England in 10 days.

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland. They wrote a book about their trip called "Sea, Ice and Rock." In 1979, Chris was working on "Quest for Adventure." He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to sail. Chris could teach Robin climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht.

They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat. Chris and Robin paddled to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was hard, but Robin was very steady. When they reached a big drop, Chris asked Robin if he had climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to climb down. Robin wanted to use his arms like on the boat, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Robin climbed down safely.

During this trip, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they go to Greenland together. Robin was a good leader. He asked everyone for their opinions before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring and hard. He liked being on land more than being at sea. Robin loved sailing and fixing things on the boat.

When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing. He was worried about Robin's safety. Climbing the highest mountain in Greenland, called the Cathedral, was very hard. They climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were very tired. Robin trusted Chris and followed him. When it was too hard, they turned back. Robin was also worried about their boat.

On the way home, there was a small problem. They took turns watching the boat. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am, but Robin did not wake him. Robin thought he could do it alone. Chris felt Robin did not trust him, and he told Robin. Robin quickly said that Chris was wrong to think that.

They enjoyed their trip to Skye, but they really got to know each other during the Greenland trip. Chris found out that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A Simple History of Apples**

Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the old types of apples.

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. Long ago, people found apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. They even stored apple halves for winter. These apples were small and wild, very different from the apples we eat today.

**Learning About Apples (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. Some apples, like the dessert apple called Decio, came from the Romans. But many Roman apples did not grow well in Britain. British monks started to grow new types of apples.

**Popular Apples in the Middle Ages (1200)**  
In the 1200s, many apples became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a favorite dessert apple. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But bad times came with droughts and the Black Death, so fewer apples were grown. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent a man to France to learn more about apples. This man brought back many new apple types.

**Apples in New Lands (1750)**  
By the 1600s, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees in North America.

**New Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new type of apple from a dead tree. He named it 'Hawkey.' At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and said it was 'Delicious!' This apple became very popular. 

**Granny Smith Apple (1850)**  
In Australia, Maria Anne Smith found a small apple tree in 1868. She took care of it and grew green apples. People called her 'Granny Smith.' She believed that good things can come from what we think is trash.

**Today’s Apples (1950)**  
Now, apples are grown all over the world. But most apples come from just a few types. Many of these apples look good but do not taste very good. Some old apple types are still grown by gardeners in the UK, but many have disappeared in the US. People want more types of apples. We should care about keeping different kinds of apples for everyone.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a travel company that offers exciting trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique places and interesting activities. Our brochure has over 100 adventures, like tours, hikes, safaris, and explorations, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

We travel in small groups of about 16 people. This makes it easier to learn about the places we visit. You can meet local people and see their culture closely. It is a fun experience for everyone.

**Different Ways to Travel**

We use many types of transport on our trips. Sometimes we travel by bus, train, boat, or even on foot. Each trip is special and shows the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people who like to try new things. Most are from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone who is healthy, fit, and open to new experiences. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. Some travel as couples, while others travel alone.

**Activities and Interests**

Every trip is different. We have 8 categories of adventures, each with special activities. These include cultural experiences, wildlife safaris, and hiking. 

**Cultural Adventures**

Many trips focus on local cultures and history. For example, you can visit Egypt, India, or Greece to see famous sites and learn about different cultures. We often take short walks to see unique places.

**Wildlife Safaris**

Our wildlife safaris let you see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can walk in the wild and see animals up close. You can also camp or stay in hotels during these trips.

**Meeting Local People**

A special part of our trips is meeting local tribes and ethnic groups. You can learn about their lives and cultures. We travel in small groups to help understand and respect different cultures.

**Easy and Moderate Hiking**

Some trips include easy walks in beautiful countryside. You can stay in hotels or local homes. We have trips in places like Spain, Greece, and Thailand. Your big luggage is carried for you, so you only need a small bag for the day.

**Major Treks**

For strong walkers, we offer challenging hikes in high mountains. You can stay with local people or camp in beautiful areas. We have support to help carry your things.

**Wilderness Experiences**

Discovering remote areas is an exciting adventure. You can explore places like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These trips are for those who want to see amazing nature.

**Sailing and River Journeys**

We also have relaxing trips on boats. You can sail in Egypt or take a river journey in places like India and Africa. No experience is needed, and we teach you how to stay safe.

Explore Worldwide offers many adventures for everyone who loves to travel and discover new places!

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners. He visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is in the mountains, ten miles south of the equator. The camp is near Mount Kenya, which is the highest mountain in Kenya. For three years, Richard has trained in this beautiful but quiet place called Nanyuk.

On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard decided to train with Kenyan runners. He ran in his first race in Kenya. He also stayed at the national team training camp. This is where the best Kenyan runners prepare for big competitions. Richard was invited to the camp after he finished fifth in a big race. He was happy to have this chance.

Training in the mountains helps runners because it makes their bodies better at using oxygen. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful. Richard's first race in Africa was special because it was the first international cross-country race in Africa. Many Kenyan runners finished ahead of him, but he felt good about his race.

Kenyan runners are known for their simple way of training. They run easily and enjoy competing. Richard learned how they train at the camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, high up on Mount Kenya. The runners live with other students in simple rooms. 

Every day, they have three training sessions. They start with an easy morning run, then do hard training in the middle of the day, and finish with another run in the afternoon. They run about 40 kilometres each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometres.

Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with a dish called ugali, stew, and vegetables. After running, they go to a stream to wash.

By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just because of their genes or where they live. It is also about their simple life, hard work, and love for running. These things help them become the best in long-distance running.

**Simplified Text:**

Advertising is not doing well. This problem started in 1989, before the economy got bad. Advertising is not keeping up with changes in the economy. Advertisers think about big groups of people, but now there are many different groups. Even big brands do not always target the right people.

Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Most of these items are not from brands you see in ads. You might only buy a few advertised brands. In a year, you probably buy about 400 different brands. But there are many more brands advertised, about 32,500. Most people only buy a small number of these brands.

When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that only 1 in 16 ads is for something they will buy. This means that many ads are not useful. People do not buy most of the brands they see in ads.

Advertising can still work well. It needs to reach many people to find the few who will buy. Advertisers cannot know who will buy their products. Even when they try to target specific people, they cannot reach everyone. 

If an advertiser can get one million new customers, that is good. For many products, getting 2 percent of the population is a big success. To do better, advertising needs to focus more on the right people.

Text: 'Solar Survivor Charles Clover visits a very green home in Britain. This home is in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. Southwell has some surprises. The first is Southwell Minster, a little-known old cathedral. It has special carvings of 'green' men made by craftsmen long ago. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house', built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 

The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking. They recycle waste into compost for their garden. They also heat their house with heat from their appliances and their own bodies, plus the heat from their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and is near the Minster. It was built to match the old buildings in the town and got permission to be built even in a protected area.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, it is very quiet. The house is very well insulated, so you cannot hear anything inside. When you go inside and take off your shoes, it is very calm. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air. Robert opens special windows to let fresh air in. The house is designed to keep out drafts, even the cats have their own small door.

The Vales teach architecture at Nottingham University. They cared about the environment long before it was popular. They wrote a book about green homes in the 1970s called The Autonomous House. They wanted to build a house that did not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to not use mains water. They made special toilets and put rainwater tanks in the cellar. They use copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean, which they filter before using. Water from washing goes into the garden. The Vales do not use a dishwasher because they think strong detergents are not good for the environment.

Robert says, "We want people to see that it is possible to build a house that is better for the environment, without living in the dark." The house looks a little old-fashioned inside, with a tall hall that has a fireplace and stairs. The Vales do not pay water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, which is very low. Soon, they will add solar panels to make even more electricity. The house will use some electricity from the mains for cooking but will make extra electricity. One day, they hope to charge an electric car with it.

The only heat in the house comes from a small wood stove, which they only use when it is very cold. When Robert was asked if it is warm in winter, he said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature was 18C, which is lower than usual, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no drafts. He believes that people used to feel warm in colder homes because of their clothing. 

The house is simple and easy to maintain. Most materials were bought from local shops and built by local workers. This made the house cheap to build, the same price as low-cost rental homes. Many big building companies do not like this idea.'

Text: 'The Camera and Fairies

Arthur Conan Doyle made the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a smart man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw pictures of fairies in a garden. He believed these pictures showed that fairies were real. He wrote an article and shared the pictures, saying fairies are wonderful.

In 1939, the two women who took the pictures said they were fake. They cut out fairy pictures from a book and put them in flowers. The pictures looked nice, but the trick was simple. This shows that a camera can lie. 

Today, we can change pictures with computers. People think photography was always real, but that is not true. From the start, cameras changed what we see.'

**Blacksmiths**

For a long time, people have been interested in iron. Blacksmiths are the people who work with iron. In the past, blacksmiths were very important. They made weapons, armor, and tools for farming. They were as respected as doctors. 

In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for buildings like St Paul's Cathedral. But by the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain. Factories did not need them anymore, and new buildings did not use their beautiful work.

In the last 10 years, blacksmithing has become popular again. People like decorative buildings and new designs. However, some of the new work looks old-fashioned. Many shops sell items that look like they are from the past.

There are events to help blacksmiths. One event is an exhibition of ironwork by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). It opened last week in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says this could be a new time for blacksmiths. 

Now, blacksmiths can use power tools. This makes it easier for them to work with metal. They can bend and shape iron more easily. About 250 pieces of ironwork are in the show, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most money will go to the blacksmiths, but some will help the Association.

Alan Dawson has made a big gate and a lamp. He says, "I let the steel bend and flow when it is hot. It is like drawing with metal." Many artists love working with iron. It is soft when hot but becomes hard when it cools down. 

Susan May, a jeweller, says, "It is magical. It is soft when hot, but hard when cold." Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard. It feels like it will last forever."

Iron is a special metal. It makes people feel safe and happy. It will likely be used for decoration for many years, as long as we do not see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Stopped Smoking**

I thought my friends would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one person was very angry. She asked, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I could not explain how I went from smoking a lot to not smoking at all in just a few hours. 

Two months and three weeks ago, I went to a stop-smoking class. I did not plan to stop smoking. I did not really want to stop. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking, and I still feel that way. I was healthy and did not often get sick. 

That Thursday, I went to the class to write about it, not to stop smoking. I said, "I will not try to stop. I am here to write." I liked smoking. It made me happy. The teacher looked at me like she understood. 

In the class, we could smoke as much as we wanted. The room was full of smoke, and we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I did not want to. The messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. I began to think that maybe I could stop. 

It was not hard to stop. The feeling of wanting a cigarette went away after a minute or two. I felt this for only four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was easy. 

The hardest part for me was being at home on weekends. I realized that smoking helped me not feel bored. I do miss smoking a little, but not too much. Now, every time I eat out, wait for a plane, check into a hotel, or take a break at the theater, I remember that I used to smoke.

**Text: Dorothy Hodgkin**

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British woman scientist. She won the Nobel Prize, which is a very important award. But many people in Britain do not know her name. 

For four years, I have asked my friends about Dorothy Hodgkin. I tell them I am writing a book about her. If they know who she is, they pass my test. 

Dorothy Hodgkin is special because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. Many famous writers are well-known, but Dorothy is not. She died in 1994. She was a great scientist and studied crystals. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like better education for women and the growth of science around the world.

When I started my research, I wanted to read about other scientists. A friend told me about Linus Pauling, who was also a scientist and a friend of Dorothy. I went to a bookshop to find a book about him, but there were none. I was surprised because he was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes too.

Some scientists think that stories about scientists are boring. Peter Medawar, a famous scientist, said that the lives of scientists are not interesting to read. If scientists think this, then publishers and bookshops might think so too. 

People often see scientists as different from artists or writers. But scientists can have interesting lives too. Some scientists do not want to be in the media because they do not want to seem like they are showing off. This can make young people less interested in science.

Today, more scientists are seen in public. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on TV, and geneticist Steve Jones advertises cars. These activities help people see scientists as real people.

The way we write about scientists is changing. Before, books about scientists were often boring. They did not talk much about their personal lives. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" show that scientists can have fun and interesting lives. 

Dorothy Hodgkin worked hard in science. She found out the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in 1964. She also worked on insulin. She had three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life is important too. 

Dorothy loved science, and this was very important for her success. It is hard to explain this passion to readers. Many people do not know enough science to understand complex ideas. But learning science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language. 

It is sad that many educated people do not know about great scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help because their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a well-drilling business. They use machines to drill wells, but Margaret only needs her stick to find water. They find water more than 90% of the time.

This skill is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special sense. There are many ideas about how it works. One idea is that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers can feel these vibrations. Others say they can smell water.

Recently, many farmers have needed help because of dry weather. Margaret usually sees each customer only once because wells last a long time. Some customers have cottages or barns where they want water. Others are building golf courses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to avoid waste in the water. The water she finds is clean, but she must be careful about minerals like iron. She also needs electricity to pump the water, so the well should be close to power sources.

To find water, Margaret first looks at a map. She uses a pendulum, which swings over areas with water. After that, she walks with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels something strange. She uses the stick to find the best spot to drill. 

Margaret holds the stick with both hands. If the stick rises, it means water is below. It is important to drill in the right place. If she and her husband do not agree on where to drill, they keep looking until they do.

Margaret's skill is not just a local tradition. Many people are interested in how she finds water. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of understanding her surroundings. This skill helps her family run their well-drilling business every year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever wanted to live someone else's life for a day? It could be fun to try something new! We helped four people do this. Here are their stories.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda is 23 years old and has two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 

Amanda went to the restaurant and was surprised. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her home. She had to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. It was hard! The drinks fell and spilled everywhere. Amanda felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said it was okay. 

When the restaurant opened, many customers came. Amanda was nervous about remembering their orders, but the computer helped her. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. She had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. 

At the end of her shift, Amanda was very tired. She was happy to go back to her children. She learned that being a waitress is not easy!

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy is 30 years old and swapped lives with Amanda. She was nervous about being a mother for a day. 

Cindy had to get Amanda's two daughters ready. After dropping one daughter at school and the other at nursery, she thought she would have some quiet time. But she had to clean the house and do laundry! 

When the girls came home, they played and made a mess. Cindy tried to relax, but it was hard. She was tired by the end of the day. She learned that taking care of children is very tiring, but she also had fun.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary is 42 years old and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a teacher. 

On the farm, Rosemary wakes up very early. At school, she felt nervous in front of many students. She helped with math and a nature project. The teachers had little time to eat. 

Rosemary enjoyed a reading lesson and a French lesson, but she was tired. Speaking in front of the class was hard for her. She decided that she prefers farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary is 30 years old and went to Rosemary's farm. She arrived early but found out that Rosemary had been working for hours. 

Hilary helped in the ice-cream shop and bottled milk. She had to check the sheep and help them if they fell. Milking the cows took a long time, and it was lonely work. 

Hilary missed being with children. She learned that farming is hard work and not as easy as it seems. 

**Conclusion**

These four people learned a lot by swapping lives for a day. They found out that every job has its challenges and rewards!

Text: 'A trumpet is not just for Christmas. Many musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a special trumpet player from southern Sweden. He is 30 years old and is known all over the world. He plays old music and new music. When you see him, he looks young and happy, just like the sound of his trumpet. 

When he was eight years old, his father gave him a real trumpet for Christmas. His father liked Louis Armstrong's music. Hakan loved the trumpet and played it all the time. His mother found a trumpet teacher for him. The teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw that Hakan had talent. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher.

Hardenberger says that the trumpet is not a perfect instrument. Every trumpet has small problems. He learned to understand these problems and work with them. Even when he was a boy, people could hear his special sound. 

Unlike another famous trumpet player, John Wallace, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He looked up to a French trumpet player named Maurice Andre. Hakan's parents helped him practice and supported his dream to be a trumpet player.

At 15, Hakan needed to choose where to study. He could not go to America, so he went to Paris at 16 to learn from Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra is not as good as being a solo player. Hakan knew he played better than many other young players. 

When he was 17, he entered a competition in Paris. He only learned some pieces for the first round, but he did well and moved to the second round. In the final round, he faced a hard piece. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing. He realized that even if he thought he played badly, people still listened to him.

Hardenberger is honest about his music. He does not want to explain his special talent because he thinks it might go away. He believes that music can always touch people's hearts.'

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in a made-up country called Efica. It is a special tale about people, history, and humor. The writer has made a world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows the writer's unique ideas. It is a hard book to read, but it is worth it.

B. Harriet is a woman with a good job and a nice husband. She usually does not meet Sheila, a working-class woman. Sheila takes care of her old father and her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo hurts Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about what happened. Leo was a good student and never fought before. He does not know why he did it. Joe gets better but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son and takes care of him all the time. Sheila feels very guilty and wants to meet Harriet. This meeting helps them become friends. The writer shows how people react when their lives change. He also shows how mothers feel they can never do enough for their children.

C. This book is on the shortlist for the Booker prize. It tells the story of a lonely island in Scotland and its people over a long time. The story includes important moments in Scottish history. A young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson dreams about these moments. He disappears for a while and comes back after the Second World War. He learns to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his big success, the writer has made a new book that is funny and looks at family life. Fifteen years after her daughter died, Aurora Greenway is almost seventy. She has a lively friend named Rosie. Aurora is still charming and kind, and Rosie helps her with her friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is here. The writer shows the sadness that is often hidden in everyday life.

E. Six different people come together because of a rich man named Logan Urquhart. He takes them on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit, to sail around the South Pacific islands. The writer uses beautiful words to tell the personal stories of these sailors. They learn about themselves while sailing on the ocean. The writer uses strong images to show ideas about memory and awareness. These images can be strange but also help us understand.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs. They share what they like, what they don’t like, and what they do every day.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am. I go to the gym at 7 am and get to work by 8 am. I start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgery on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. It can be stressful to decide what to do. I feel okay when I operate, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is very important, and when it works, it is great. From 10 am to 1 pm, I meet with patients to explain their operations. I like this part of my job. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Sometimes, I have to work at night or on weekends. When I am on holiday, I still think about my patients."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am and leave home by 8:20 am. I take the train to work and arrive at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to talk about our work. I work with a team of designers. I spend three to four weeks designing projects. After that, I show my ideas to the client. If they like my ideas, we make plans and start working with photographers and illustrators. I have to talk to many people and make sure everything is done on time. I usually have lunch at 1 pm. I get home at 7:30 pm or later. It is hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7 am most days. Some days, I wake up very early to meet flights. I might go for a bike ride or swim in the morning. I have to eat healthy food because I sit a lot during my job. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. I need to know good places to eat and shop for my passengers. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7 am and leave home at 7:30 am. I work in gardens that I designed. I spend about an hour and a half at each garden. At 11 am, I go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm, and in winter until 4:30 pm. I work from home in the office too. I talk to clients in the evening about their gardens. I use old materials to make gardens look nice. It is hard to relax at night because I can hear the phone ring. I sleep well because my job is very physical."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at work by 8:30 am. I help build bridges and walls. I check that the workers are doing their jobs safely. I talk to the workers and solve problems. The workers start at 6 am, so I find out what happened since I left. I usually have lunch from 2 pm to 2:30 pm. I eat quickly while I work. I leave work at about 6 pm, but I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Work Day**

A. **Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and go to work by 7:30 am. I help customers who use our credit cards. I talk to card users and try to get new ones. I also work with other companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and then I check my emails. I have many meetings during the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different places in Europe once or twice a week. I finish work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

B. **Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am. I check the mail and listen to about ten to twenty music tapes each day. I have meetings to talk about music projects. I listen carefully to the tapes because they are very important to the people who made them. When I sign a new band, we start making their first album. I leave work at 7:00 pm and often go to music shows at night. I sometimes get home at 1:00 am.

C. **Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work to arrive at 9:30 am. I check the mail and see if we have clients visiting. I enjoy showing people our furniture and selling it. We sell old furniture that costs between £1,000 and £6,000. I also talk to people who fix the furniture. I read a magazine about antiques while I drink coffee. I do the accounts once a month and go home at 5:30 pm.

D. **Air Traffic Controller**  
I leave home at 6:00 am for my early shift. I start work at 7:00 am and help control the planes. I work in a team with other controllers. In winter, we manage about 1,000 planes a day. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new rules. This job is stressful, and I want to be a manager one day.

E. **Shop Manager**  
If I work early, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the cash register and help customers find books. I enjoy helping them, but sometimes it can be hard. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, I meet with book publishers to talk about new books. I finish my early shift at 5:45 pm. On some days, I work late and close the shop.

F. **Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then I get ready for work. I take a taxi and arrive at 8:45 am. I talk to reporters to find out what is happening in the area I cover. I help companies understand financial risks. I write reports and send them to my editor. I travel to Africa three times a year for work. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. What is a good leader? A leader is someone who inspires others and helps them change for the better. Being a leader is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about work, says that a leader makes things happen with the help of enthusiastic people. A good leader should speak clearly and confidently. They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says that many people can be great leaders if they see their own talents and use them. We all have the ability to be leaders; we just need the right situation to grow. It is easy to see famous leaders like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can be harder to see leadership in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they do it? The best boss motivated you and supported you. The worst boss made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first boss led well; the second boss managed badly.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within rules. Leaders create new ideas. Micheal Shea, who writes about leadership, says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad company into a happy one.

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:
- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find what you care about and use that energy to lead.
- Think of yourself as a leader. You have the power to lead.
- Sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different ways of leading. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking charge instead. See how this changes things.
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better.

F. Leadership does not just happen. You need to take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, and give praise. 
- Don’t think everyone will like your way of leading right away. Keep working on how you communicate. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be good.
- Be present and available to important people. 
- Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video**

**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent movies.**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a tense movie about oil workers and navy experts. They try to save a nuclear submarine that is stuck deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team are brave and funny. The special effects in the movie are very good, but the story is not very strong.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about a battle in Guadalcanal. Director Andrew Marton made a more traditional war movie. He focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Another version of this story by Terrence Malick is more artistic, but Marton's film has some good moments, like when the soldier dreams of his wife.

**C. On Guard**  
This fun movie is based on a book from 1875. It has a bad guy played by Fabrice Luchini, who causes trouble. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, and Daniel Auteuil plays a swordsman. The movie is full of action and humor, making it enjoyable to watch.

**D. Character**  
This movie is set in Rotterdam a long time ago. The costumes and sets look very real, like a museum. Jan Decleir plays a cruel bailiff named Dreverhaven, who is mean to his tenants. The story is about his bad relationship with his son, but the movie focuses too much on the details instead of the story.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This movie has been remastered and looks great. The sound is very clear, and you can hear every little noise. The story is about three men: the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach). They all do bad things in the Wild West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This is a long war movie with many famous actors. It has four directors and thousands of extras. The beginning is slow, as soldiers wait for news about an invasion. The movie is impressive, but it is better to watch on a big screen than on video.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is a very interesting story. The main character is a lawyer. He has to start a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife because she is accused of killing her husband. The trial is exciting, and we do not know what will happen until the end. There is a big surprise at the end of the book. This is a great first book.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. The main character, Sigismondo, helps rich people in Italy during the Renaissance. He gets into a lot of trouble with politics and murder, but we know he will find the bad people. The story is a bit complicated and too long, but it is still very good.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. The main character, Leah Hunter, is a tax inspector. She starts to investigate when a strange man dies near her. Leah is brave and smart, and she does not let anyone stop her, even the local detective who does not like her.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker is about a private investigator named Spenser. He helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The story has fast dialogue and some deep thoughts, but there are not many deaths. It is always good entertainment from Parker.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has two detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a robbery at the home of a famous actress's daughter. The author's easy writing and interesting characters make this a fun mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife, Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It is about a lawyer and a female client, but most of the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim in the story. It has romance, money, and violence, making it a very exciting book.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a victim. Many funny characters come together to make a Robin Hood movie, but Philip does not like how his career is going. Simon Shaw usually entertains us, but this time the story is not as good as his other works.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is the best book by Lawrence Gough in a long time. Canadian police are looking for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the smart but troubled robber, making it better than most detective novels.

I might be too old for this, but here I go! Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age want to travel. This summer, he quit his job and decided to rent his flat. He wants to travel in South East Asia for a year. Some people think he is lucky, but he feels nervous. He has traveled before. After university, he backpacked in North and South America for two years. When he came back, he wanted to travel again. But then he fell in love, got a job, and bought a flat.
