He realized he was not happy just working for money. When he quit his job, he felt free again. 

Many of his friends are now married and have children. They do not want to change places with him, but they wish they had his freedom. Tim is not in a relationship and does not have big career goals. He feels he should enjoy his freedom for his friends. But he is still nervous. He has to make plans. He worries about someone else living in his home. He also needs to decide where to go. He is a big procrastinator and is already behind on his plans. He thinks, "Maybe I should just enjoy summer in England." 

Tim wonders if he can still backpack. Will he be okay living simply? Will he feel out of place with younger backpackers? Many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel and leave their old lives. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says more people are realizing they can have adventures if they are brave and organized. 

Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says he is ready to give up job security for this trip. He knows he will come back to the same job position, but he thinks it is worth the risk. 

Matt, who just left the Army, says traveling helped him change. He needed to learn to live differently. There are many reasons people travel at this age. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says more people have flexible jobs. If a job ends, they have nothing to lose. Some companies even allow career breaks. 

Dan Hiscocks, from a travel publishing company, says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. If they are not happy, they know they can change. Travel helps them think about what they want. 

Jennifer Cox believes this is not a sign of not wanting to grow up. It shows that people want a balanced life. Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher, is going to Central America for a year. He does not think he is running away. He wants to find things for himself. But he feels nervous about leaving his comfortable life. 

I also feel nervous about leaving my easy life. I might not be going if I had not found my boss so hard to work with. Jennifer Cox says this is common. Sometimes a big change, like a breakup or losing a job, pushes people to travel. 

I am excited about the next year. No matter what happens, I will be happy that I took this chance. I think many older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt lost because of new technology. Here, she tells how she changed her home into a good place to work.

Last Christmas, I turned 37 years old. I realized I needed to get back to my job in journalism. I looked at my resume and saw that I was stuck in the past. I used to type on a typewriter, and now computers were everywhere. I thought no one would want me in a newsroom because I did not know how to use a computer. Many job ads asked for skills in desktop publishing, but I had none. I felt scared to use a computer.

I thought it would be hard to leave home to work. But then, I entered a contest in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer! We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for everyone. We started to learn about the Internet and how to chat with people from around the world. The kids stopped watching TV, and I made a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home and still take the kids to school.

The children were good with computers because they learned at school. I was nervous and thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. But I learned the basic skills I needed. It was easier than I thought. I started to write articles for a magazine, and now I feel happy because I can work and be with my family.

The computer helped me a lot. Before, my desk was messy, and I lost important papers. Now, I am more organized. I can keep track of money and use templates for letters and invoices. With the Internet, I can find information for my stories and talk to other journalists from around the world.

But working from home has some problems. I can feel lonely because I don’t see people often. There are also distractions at home, like chores and the kids wanting to use the computer. Many people in my neighborhood are also using computers for work, so we don’t have to travel to the city every day.

A report says that many people who work from home are educated and own personal computers. I feel like I am doing well. One day, I might even send my articles to a newspaper in another country or start my own magazine. The possibilities are endless!

**The Tartan Museum**

The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has modern buildings that look like cheese wedges. The outside of the museum is very big and bright with a yellow tower. Many people have different opinions about the building. Some think it is beautiful, while others do not like it.

Inside the museum, there are many interesting things to see. The museum tells stories about Scotland's history. It has important objects, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. The museum wants to show the truth about the past.

Dr. David Clarke is in charge of the exhibitions. He wants everyone to enjoy their visit, even if they do not know much about history. He does not want to use fake scenes from the past. He believes that people should see real objects and learn from them.

The museum has many spaces to explore. There are different galleries with pale walls and big windows that let in light. You can take your time to look at everything.

There is also a special area for children called the Discovery Centre. A group of kids helped create this space. They wanted to have fun and learn at the same time.

On the top floor, there is a gallery that changes every three years. It shows objects that are important to Scotland in the 20th century. People chose things like electric guitars and toys to show what mattered to them.

Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that real objects help us understand the past better than anything else. The museum is beautiful inside, but some people wonder if it is in the right place.

**Simplified Text:**

The end of print newspapers may take a long time. "Transition" is a nice word. It means moving from one place to another. Some people are scared of change, but it can also be good. 

Now, newspapers are trying to move to the internet. This is not easy. Many people think print newspapers will disappear, but this is not certain. Print newspaper sales are going down, but more people are visiting their websites. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, but their websites are getting more visitors.

However, not everything is clear. A survey showed that worldwide newspaper sales went up by 1.1% last year. In some places, like Asia, sales increased a lot. Some magazines also did well, with a 5.4% increase in sales.

E-books are becoming very popular, and many people are buying them. But when bookstores looked at their sales of physical books, they found that sales only went down by 0.4%. This means people are buying both e-books and paper books.

Many young people still read newspapers. According to a survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 read the main newspapers in the UK. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, newspaper sales dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop was only 7%. In France, it was just 3.1%.

In the past, people thought that online ads would help newspapers make money. But now, online ads are going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to get readers is to offer both a print copy and online access together. 

Print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. They make much more money from print ads than from online ads. However, it is hard for newspapers to keep both print and online versions. They need to work hard to be noticed on the internet.

**Taking Pictures of People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A picture with a person is usually better than one without. But taking good pictures of people can be hard. You need to think about how they move, their faces, and what they do. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking pictures of a group, do not have them stand in a straight line. Ask them to stand at different angles and heights. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all their faces.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting they put their hands in their pockets or fold them. 

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when you are. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel shy. You may need to help them feel comfortable.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A picture looks better if the person is looking at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They do not have to smile. If they look away, remind them to look back at the camera before you take the picture.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can look at something else in the picture. This can make the picture feel more natural. 

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
The way a person looks and moves tells us a lot about them. A happy child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for different expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up.

**G. Situation Interest**  
The background of a picture can add more meaning. Make sure the background does not take attention away from the person. 

**H. Interaction**  
Good pictures can happen when people are talking, laughing, or working together. Look for moments when people connect, like a handshake or a smile.

**I. People and Places**  
Many pictures of people are taken on trips. To show both the people and the place, step back to get everything in the picture. Make sure the people are close enough to see, but the background is also clear.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Think about why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose nicely. But for family pictures, candid shots of fun moments are often better than stiff poses. These pictures will help you remember the good times later.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is an artist. She makes special paintings called trompe-l'oeil. These paintings look real, but they are not. Joanna Watt interviews her.

Sarah does not like to sign her paintings. She thinks the painting is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble. She wants people to think her paintings paint themselves.

At first, Sarah does not want to be interviewed. She does not like to talk about herself. But after a while, she feels more comfortable, and the interview becomes fun and interesting.

Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied art for two years and learned a lot about drawing. She worked at a publishing house but did not like it. Then, she worked with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to make one trompe-l'oeil painting, and she loved it. She decided to work on her own.

Sarah says that you cannot learn trompe-l'oeil from a school. You learn by observing the world around you. She is always learning new things. She is honest about her mistakes. For example, she says, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete."

Once, she had to paint a big ceiling at Lulworth Castle. She got confused with the measurements and thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" She often talks about herself in the third person, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"

Sarah's trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special. Many people want her to paint for them. She gets ideas from buildings. For example, she made a trompe-l'oeil dining room that looks like a beautiful Italian building. 

Sarah knows that trompe-l'oeil must do two things: it must trick you and keep your attention. She believes it should also be personal for the client. She enjoys working with her clients and listening to their ideas. Many of her clients become her friends.

Sarah is thankful for her clients. She says, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, and that is why she is always busy. 

At the end of the interview, Sarah says again, "I really don't like to shout about myself." She wants her work to be quiet and not loud. But her work is very special, and more people should know about it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman talks about important skills for success at work.

A. The rules for work are changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or how much we know. We are also judged by how we manage ourselves and how we get along with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to see who will do very well at their job and who will not. These new rules are important for all jobs. They are different from what we learned in school. Doing well on tests is not as important anymore. Now, it is more about social skills and personal qualities, like being friendly, understanding others, and being flexible. These skills are called emotional intelligence.

B. Today, many jobs do not offer security. People need to have skills that they can use in different jobs. Personal qualities are becoming very important at work. We have talked about these qualities for a long time, using different names like 'character' and 'soft skills'. Now, we call them emotional intelligence. This means being aware of our own feelings and the feelings of others. It helps us think and act better. Emotional intelligence includes knowing ourselves, controlling our feelings, being motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think it just means being nice, but sometimes it means being honest, even if it is hard. It is not about showing all our feelings, but about managing them so we can work well together.

C. More companies are realizing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. The more complicated a job is, the more emotional intelligence matters. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard to use their knowledge. Many people have succeeded without strong emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s jobs, teamwork and understanding customers are very important. Emotional intelligence is essential for doing well in any job around the world.

D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people get better at managing their feelings and understanding others over time. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence and use these skills to help us in our jobs. This is important now when jobs are not always stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if we ignore it, other things may not work as well.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones make it easy to take pictures of news events. Social media has changed how people share these pictures. Now, some journalists use social media to find images of fast events. But some reporters use pictures from users without asking for permission. There are rules that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or if it is very important for the public. People still talk about whether this is right or wrong. Research shows that about one in ten people will take pictures or videos of news events. This means user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure people are paid for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine: Acupuncture**

Acupuncture is a type of medicine from China that is over 2,000 years old. It is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is often used to help with pain. Many doctors in the West use it to help people feel better.

**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**

In traditional Chinese medicine, health means that the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. There is a special energy called Qi (pronounced "chee") that flows in the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to organs in the body. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel sick or weak.

When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check your pulse, look at your tongue, and ask about your health and habits. They use very thin needles to help the flow of Qi. Sometimes, they use heat from herbs or apply pressure to certain points.

**Acupuncture Points**

There are over 300 points on the meridians where acupuncturists can place needles. These points may not be close to where you feel pain. People often feel a gentle ache or tingling when the needle is used. This means the needle is working with the Qi.

**How Does Acupuncture Work?**

Doctors in the West believe acupuncture can help with pain, even if they do not follow traditional Chinese ideas. They think that acupuncture can block pain signals or release natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.

**What Pain Can Acupuncture Help?**

Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. It can help with back pain, headaches, arthritis, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain and pain from serious illnesses.

**Using Acupuncture in Modern Medicine**

Acupuncture has been used in China for a long time, but using it during surgery started in the 1950s. Now, it is used in many types of surgeries in China. Some people say it helps reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia.

**Is Acupuncture Always Effective?**

Studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find acupuncture helps with chronic pain. It may take several visits to feel better, but some people feel improvement after just a few sessions.

**A Different Way to Treat Pain**

Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They ask many questions to understand what might be causing the pain. They consider things like weather and how the pain feels. This is different from how many doctors in the West think about pain.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist. If needed, they should refer you to a medical doctor for more help.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her real name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very calm and strong, like a headmistress of a school. But she is also shy. She says that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, is like her if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James likes to write alone. She needs quiet time to write.

Many people read her books. She has written 12 detective novels. She likes to read books by women writers, but she also enjoys books by some men. P.D. James became successful when she was older. She was 42 when her first book, Cover Her Face, was published. 

P.D. James was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there. Life was not easy for her. Her husband was very sick after the war, and she had to work hard to take care of him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped her with the children.

P.D. James worked for the National Health Service and then for the Home Office. She saw many dead bodies while working in forensic science, but she was not interested in death. She loved writing detective stories because they helped her understand people. She wanted to be a serious writer. She believes that writing about crime can help make sense of life.

**Simplified Text:**

The pen is stronger than the psychoanalyst. People are studying handwriting to learn about a person's character. In some countries, if you want a job, you may need to show your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. 

Handwriting analysis, called graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Some researchers say it can help find certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer. It can also show how a person feels. Many companies now use graphologists to look at the handwriting of job candidates. 

However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not sure if graphology is useful. Patricia Marne is a graphologist with over 20 years of experience. She thinks handwriting can show psychological traits and health issues. She says, "Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if someone should study arts or sciences."

Ms. Marne believes graphology can help find people who might commit crimes. She says criminals often have bad handwriting. This can show they have emotional problems. She can tell if someone is honest or not just by looking at their handwriting. 

Ms. Marne says that handwriting can show if someone is under stress or has mental health issues. Changes in handwriting over time can mean something serious is happening. 

She also says that handwriting can show other traits. For example, if letters are connected like threads, the person may be clever but not honest. Writing mostly in capital letters can mean someone is hiding their true self. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity. 

Ms. Marne believes it takes six years to learn how to analyze handwriting well. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She believes it can be more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can show a person's history without asking questions. 

However, some psychiatrists do not agree. They say handwriting is just a result of education and has no other meaning.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**

Fresh air and good chairs are important for happy and healthy workers, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies work conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here is what they said.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple. It has no central heating and no air conditioning. The windows open to the street. The workers are part of a small team and seem happy. They change the office temperature by opening doors or using electric heaters, like at home. This may help them feel comfortable.
  
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture does not match. Some chairs are old and broken, which is not good for sitting. But the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations. This variety helps them not feel tired or bored.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff like the different types of work and the size of the office. It is small enough to know what others are doing but big enough to work alone. The office looks nice and fun.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable. The air is good, and there is a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has good chairs and lighting. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. The walls are plain and not very interesting.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls have some planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most workers have been there for a long time and get along well. The office could be better if desks were arranged to share information easily.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office gets mixed feelings from workers. It feels like being in a glass box. The air is not stale, even with smokers around.

- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and not inspiring. The desks are okay, but some chairs are not good for working on computers. 

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff help each other and use technology well. There are many awards on display. The office is busy.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many problems. The air conditioning does not work well, and the temperature changes a lot. The space is messy, and there is a lot of dust.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is not good for a modern office. Many chairs are old and do not help workers sit properly.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office is dirty, with old chairs and carpets. It needs cleaning and better air conditioning. Workers seemed stressed and not happy. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular in America. People chew 12 million sticks of gum every day. It is a food and has very few calories. 

Today, gum is made with special ingredients to keep the flavor and make it soft. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a type of gum from a tree in Greece and Turkey. Women in Greece used it to clean their teeth and make their breath smell nice. 

In America, colonists learned to chew gum from the Native Americans. They chewed a resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people sold this spruce gum in the eastern United States. 

Modern gum started in the late 1860s when people found chicle, a substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and better to chew. However, it is hard to grow sapodilla trees, so now most gum is made with synthetic materials. 

Today, there are few people who collect chicle. They have a hard life. They walk for miles in hot and dangerous places to get the sap. They must be careful of snakes and insects. They climb trees to collect the sap and take it to a camp where they boil it to make gum. 

Life at the camp is tough. They eat a simple diet and drink local alcohol. Even though their work is hard, these collectors worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported a lot of chicle, but now much less is collected. 

As gum sales have increased, companies use synthetic materials to make gum cheaper. Gum is also marketed in many ways. People say gum helps you relax and can reduce tooth decay. Chewing gum can help your mouth produce more saliva, which is good for your teeth. 

Companies are always looking for new flavors and textures for gum. Some flavors are natural, but many are artificial. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the most popular chewing gums.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The hotel is quiet and has Indian decorations. The Ghanerao family has lived there for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel has basic facilities, like hot water from a bucket, but this makes it special.

B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing a mountain. After a long climb, I was surprised to see this hotel in a beautiful place. It is very high up and surrounded by nature. It was amazing to find such luxury after a hard day of climbing.

C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
Paradis Hotel is on a quiet part of Mauritius. The hotel is on its own peninsula. The road to the hotel goes by empty beaches. The hotel is big and has many activities, but you can find peace on the nine-kilometer private beach. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you can relax and feel far away from everything.

D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
Ladera Hotel is in St Lucia and has a beautiful view of the Caribbean Sea. It is quiet and high up, with open rooms that look out at the sea. The hotel has a colonial style with nice wooden furniture and big beds.

E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada, one of the Princes Islands. It is a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. The islands are peaceful, with no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is old and charming, with white wood and red domes.

F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, there is a beautiful old chateau. It has a moat and swans. The chateau has 20 different rooms, some with big beds. They offer special weekend deals with breakfast, dinner, and champagne.

G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel in Nairobi is a comfortable place for travelers. It is not fancy but very nice. Many guests come to relax after a safari. The hotel has beautiful gardens and cozy rooms. It is a great place to enjoy the sunset and have a good dinner.

H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
Hotel Splendido is famous and has welcomed many celebrities. It used to be a monastery and is now a lovely hotel. The food is simple and delicious, and the hotel has beautiful rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her work. At the Globe Hotel, things are not going well. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not see Sue and Christopher. Sue thinks this is very bad. 

The Globe Hotel has three red stars. This means it is one of the best hotels. But the hotel is not welcoming. The entrance is hard to find, and the door is not manned. Sue is not happy. 

When they check in, the receptionist says they have no record of the booking. There are 15 rooms, but many are empty. The room they get is not nice. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall. 

Sue has a reputation for being tough. She remembers when people called her "The Woman in Black," even though she did not wear black. The next morning, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. 

Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and not showing guests to the bad room. Robin takes notes and looks worried. He has only worked at the hotel for five months. 

Sue also praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good work. The dinner is good, and the hotel keeps its two-rosette food rating. Robin asks how to get three rosettes. Sue says they should not serve bad desserts. 

Sue's job is to tell the truth about the hotel, even if it is hard. Sometimes, people complain about her. She has to write a report about what she finds. The hotel pays for her help. 

The good news for Robin is that Sue will not take away the red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems are fixed. Robin smiles, but he does not look happy.

**Seven Summits: Climbing the Highest Mountains**

Doug Scott is a mountaineer. He climbed the highest mountain on each continent. This is called the Seven Summits. He tells us about his climbs.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his friend Dougal were climbing Mt. Everest. They were in a snow cave when Dougal talked about sleeping bags. Doug thought this was strange because they were alone. He started talking to his feet because they were cold. They were worried about how to survive. Doug felt calm because he trusted Dougal. He found a good way to climb and reached the top.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Mt. McKinley is a very hard mountain to climb. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal carried their things to the base of the mountain. They climbed a new route. They carried their food and equipment on their backs. They camped under a cliff. The weather was bad, and they were tired. Finally, they reached the top and felt happy.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul wanted to climb Mt. Kenya. They got a free ride to Kilimanjaro instead. They got lost in the jungle and needed water. They found a rock pool and were very happy. They tried to climb a steep wall but decided to take a safer route to the top.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife Sharu went to Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil. They decided to climb with him. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The wind was strong, but they reached the top and camped outside. They met other climbers who wanted to climb the Seven Summits too.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif needed money. He and his team left for the South Pole in November 1992. The sun was always shining. On December 7, they climbed to the top in a storm. It was very cold, but they were happy to reach the summit.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In summer 1994, Doug's team met in St Petersburg. They took a cable car up Elbrus. They walked to a refuge. After two days, they climbed to what they thought was the top. But there was more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then went down the mountain.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
Doug wanted to climb Carstensz and meet the local Dani people. They were warned about dangers but still went. On May 12, they climbed the mountain. The weather got better, and they reached the top. Doug was very happy to finish climbing all seven summits!

**Style Merchants**

Style is important in our lives today. It is in our clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley shares some fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says, "People should choose simple styles instead of stiff and frilly dresses." He has been drawing wedding dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You do not have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress. He also makes long evening dresses in new colors and fabrics. For those who like classic styles, he designs a navy-blue suit that many women wore in the 20th century. But his version looks very modern.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not study jewellery. She started designing rings when she could not find one she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Many famous people want her jewellery. She uses large semi-precious stones in gold to make beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings. Recently, she started using diamonds. She says, "I wanted a diamond, so I began to work with them."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson started her handbag business four years ago. She only took a short art course. Two of her bags were chosen for a big design show. All her bags are handmade in the UK. A Grimson handbag is not just a bag; it is stylish and made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk. 

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people have had their hair done by him. He says, "Most women want hair that looks real and is easy to style at home." He wants his clients to look natural, not like they just came from a salon. His first appointment costs £250, and there is a long waiting list. He also sells his own hairdryers and styling tools for people to use at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and helps supermarkets and restaurants with flower ideas. She has no formal training in flowers and used to be a teacher. She started her flower business 10 years ago. Her modern flower arrangements have won many awards. She also teaches at her own London Flower School and has given lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, "Flower arrangements are simpler now. Keep them strong and do not use too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, use flowers of the same type."

Text: 'The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both guests and staff. 

The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know the guests' names. He uses a computer system to remember what guests like. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost a lot of money to set up, but it will help the hotel save money in the future. 

For example, if a guest asks for certain music during their first stay, the hotel will have that music ready for them when they come back. 

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can set it between 14°C and 25°C. 

The hotel also has special technology for business guests. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel is ready for new technology and can change things easily. 

The rooms are comfortable and welcoming. There are 145 bedrooms, a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. 

The food is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has made a new kitchen that is modern. 

With great food, good technology, and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.'

**Artist Susan Shepherd and Her Garden**

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her garden is very big and has many flowers. She loves tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. 

There are two long flower beds along a path in the garden. The colors and shapes of the flowers are very nice. The people who owned the garden before Susan took care of it well. They left many plants that Susan likes. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She does not paint the whole garden at once. She takes a flower to her studio and paints it. This can take a few days. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. 

Spring and early summer are her busy times. This is when the tulips and poppies bloom. Susan loves how flowers change. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful. At first, they may seem boring, but they become interesting.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers that grew in hard places, like rocks.

Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely. 

Susan is busy preparing for two art shows. She has a lot of flowers to paint, but she also wants to work in her garden. She has hired another gardener to help her. She knows that to paint flowers well, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Title: The Storm and the Tree**

In March, strong storms hit the Brackham area. Many trees fell down, including two big lime trees in the town square. This made some people in the town unhappy because it changed how the town looked.

Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, was also unhappy. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. He had a headache and felt tight in his chest. His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he did not want to go. He thought the police needed him. 

Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. Pelham was too weak to argue. The doctor gave him medicine, and Molly sent him to bed. 

On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the storm. Pelham was surprised. That evening, he asked if the house was okay. When he heard it was fine, he felt relieved and went back to bed.

On Saturday, Pelham felt better. He got up and saw that without the walnut tree, the living room looked very different. The room was bright, and the old furniture looked bad. The view from the window was not nice anymore. The tall house next door, which the tree had hidden, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.

“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said to Molly. But Molly was not sad. She said, “I told you we need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

**Living in the Valley**

We lived in our valley for sixteen months. One day, we saw that the hills around us could be dangerous. It was a year when storms came early, before winter. Until then, we felt safe in our valley. 

Then, it started to snow. In one day, there was 15 centimeters of snow. The snow blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery. In the hills, the snow was deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we felt only some wind. The trees moved, but they did not break. 

We were not too worried about the snow and wind. But we were worried about the river, the Ryburn. It usually flowed gently, but now it was a problem. Many years ago, people built dams to control the water from the hills. 

Soon, the snow began to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds over the hills. The clouds looked scary and warned us of trouble. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The rain was coming down hard, and the reservoir in the hills was filling up. 

Then, the reservoir overflowed for the first time in years. Water rushed over the dam like a waterfall. The river became wild and deep near our cottage. For three days, we hoped the river would not flood our home. Luckily, the dam held, and the water went down. 

In the past, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam keeps the river safe. Most of the time, we do not worry. We can enjoy the big clouds in the sky and feel safe in our valley home.

Mark Adams is a film critic. He has worked for a newspaper called The Front Page for ten years. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before this, he wrote reviews for books and films for other newspapers and magazines. He also did some work for the radio. 

He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. Tom hired him. Tom was not a journalist, so he did not choose his staff carefully. He wanted a team of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have lunch together each week to talk about what to cover. It felt like a dream for Mark to be part of a new newspaper. He thought it was strange that a new paper could start when there were so many others. 

The first time Mark saw someone reading his review in the newspaper, he felt shy. Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned, so they talked by phone instead. People liked to have one reviewer for each subject, so Mark chose to write about films. 

Now, he writes a long piece each week about one film. He likes this way of working. He does not want to be a standard film critic who reviews every new film. That would make him tired of his job. He enjoys having space to write his thoughts. 

Mark thinks people choose films based on stars, ads, or the director. People usually stick to what they like. A person who does not like westerns is not likely to watch one just because of a review. Mark does not feel he must be right about a movie. He does not think there should be a set number of good or bad films each year. He just wants to share his opinion. He does not want to be a judge.

**Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because it is fun!**

Melanie Sears is a teenager who loves sports. She is looking for a training partner who also likes to swim, cycle, and run. She wants someone who can do all three sports without stopping. 

Triathlons are very popular in the Olympics. In a triathlon, athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without a break. Many people watch these events. But why do athletes like Melanie push themselves so hard? 

Melanie started doing triathlons when she was 14 years old. She won her first race, but she was the only junior girl there. She felt confident and entered a bigger race. She swam fast and ran fast, but she got lost and cycled too far. She cried while running, but she did not give up. 

Melanie works very hard. She trains a lot, even when it is hard. Steve Trew, a coach, says she gives everything in her training. She is very strong and finished 13th in the European Triathlon Championships this year. 

Melanie wants to buy a new bike for her races. It costs a lot of money, and her parents help her pay for it. She trains a lot and does not have much time for friends. After swimming for two hours, she just wants to sleep. But she still talks to her teammates about their training times.

Melanie has tried shorter races, but she wants to do even harder ones. She says it is hard to find friends her age to train with.

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people like this hobby. Many adults enjoy collecting. It is a fun and exciting world. But if you want to collect something, remember: you should love the item. 

People have always liked to collect. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.

I have collected many things in my life, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. When I was six years old, I started collecting stones from my parents' garden. I went to a school in a cold place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a museum. The museum had many interesting objects collected by people long ago. I loved looking at them.

Many adults also enjoy collecting. Some people collect because it is something they can control. For me, I just like it. 

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful things. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had over 4,000 paintings. But you do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I got a special tulip from another collector. I planted it, but one year it disappeared. Someone took it!

I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I looked everywhere in the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was lost in a fire. The next day, I saw the burned remains of my dolls and furniture. I was very sad.

I find it interesting how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king is very valuable. As more people want small items, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you kept the original boxes. I wish I had kept mine!

**My Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Organiser at the Science Museum**  
I put together exhibitions. I plan and design them. I also tell people about the exhibition. I read about the topic and talk to important people to find out what to show. I make sure visitors can understand the exhibition. I plan fun activities like displays and workshops. I work with engineers to keep everything safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help make brochures to tell people about it.

**Janet - Teacher for London Taxi Drivers**  
I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. I make new maps for taxi drivers to learn their routes. By noon, about 50 students are in class. They learn the best ways to drive around London. If they disagree about a turn, I help them decide. When they are close to their test, I give them a route but change it to make them think of another way. 

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, make educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but I mostly work by the coast. I work with schools and teach people about the sea. I take them on a boat to show them the life under the water. This helps them understand better. I love my job because I care about conservation, but I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is different every day. I make sure we have enough books and that they are good quality. We get letters from readers about maps, and I answer them carefully. I talk with my team about new projects and sales. I enjoy working with my team, but I have a lot of paperwork to do, which takes time away from fun tasks like designing new products.

**No Title**

We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, bought the house and made it bigger, but they did it nicely.

Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still looking for guests. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was terrible.

The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were friends in school, so we call Strafe by his last name like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. It is a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are coming because she is usually waiting in the big hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. She named our rooms after flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when few people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little things like that. Her husband takes care of repairs.

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he came into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I could tell the others felt our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good.

Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. Arthur took us to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and coming back for the rest.

After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we did not play long because we were still tired from the trip. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others going down the path to the sea.

In the morning, we would walk on the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because we had done the same things for many years. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She works in Val d'Isere, France. Sarah is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She studied French and History of Art at university. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a long-term job, but it is fun. She meets many interesting people.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. The guests eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and sometimes makes afternoon tea for the guests. She does not like cleaning the rooms because it is hard work.

By 11 a.m., Sarah goes skiing. She loves to ski and can stay on the slopes until 4:30 p.m. After skiing, she returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans the kitchen. She does not like a messy kitchen in the morning.

Sometimes Sarah talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. Good guests make her week better. Sarah meets her friends in the chalet, and they go out at night. They usually go to places like Bananas and G Jay's.

On Sundays, Sarah works very hard. She wakes up early to make breakfast for guests who are leaving. After they go, she cleans the chalet quickly. If she has not done the shopping, she does it now. At about 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at 4:30 p.m. 

Sometimes the new guests have many questions. Sarah helps them get boots or skis from the ski shop. After that, she gets ready for dinner again. Sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with light skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore big shoes and overalls, and her hair was messy but framed her pretty face. Seymour was surprised that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research about leather in New Jersey for her Master's degree.

A few times a year, people called or wrote to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he helped students by answering their questions or giving them a short tour. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class who visited the factory years ago. Seymour showed them how he made gloves, especially Marie's favorite part, the laying-off table. At this table, the workers shaped and pressed each glove using hot brass hands. Marie thought these hands looked strange and called them "pancake hands."

Rita asked Seymour, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come to your shipping department?" Seymour explained, "They come to the tannery. The tannery makes the leather for us. My grandfather and father worked there, and I did too for six months. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour said, "You should go if you want to write about leather. I can help you visit one. It’s an old place, and the work is hard. Tanning is one of the oldest jobs in the world. They found tanning tools that are six thousand years old in Turkey. The first clothes were just animal skins that were smoked to make them soft."

Seymour continued, "My father knows a lot about leather. If you talk to him about gloves, he can talk for two days! Glovemen love their work. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" Rita replied, "Not really. I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." Seymour laughed. He liked her spirit and eagerness to learn. 

Rita was much smaller than Marie, but she reminded him of her. Marie was always happy and full of what she learned in school. She wrote everything down and remembered it well. Seymour said, "Let's do something fun. We will show you how to make gloves from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Hard Job?**

Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs to see if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. Raquel is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job but has one problem: she does not like flying. "On a long flight to California, I take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. "It felt very small with tiny windows." When she is not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork like organizing schedules and going to meetings. Raquel did not apply for this job. She met a pop group manager by chance and took a secretarial course at night. Five years later, her boss needed a personal assistant, and she got the job.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy. A caddy carries a golfer's bags. David likes being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are some problems. He earns a small fee and a part of the winnings. He makes between £25,000 and £35,000, but he spends a lot on travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You do more than carry bags. You give advice and try to understand the course," he says. Now, he also works with European Tour Productions to collect and analyze golf statistics.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easy tasks is to try food in fancy restaurants. He thinks that expensive meals are okay for those who can pay. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave," he says. Martin became a food writer because a friend offered him a food column. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "I had to take a pay cut, but it was a chance to do what I love," he says. He still cooks at home and rides his bike to stay fit.

**D. Dick Prince**  
Dick Prince is a popular children's writer in Britain. "I started writing children's stories 20 years ago," he says. Before that, he loved words and wrote poems. He got the idea for his first story, "The Fox Busters," from his experience as a farmer. He wrote about chickens and a fox. Dick says, "It is not easy to find ideas. I work on them in the mornings." He does not wake up very early. After lunch, he types his notes on an old typewriter. He gets 50 to 100 letters a week from fans, which he enjoys. He tries to answer them all but has some help now.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story building. Outside, there were big piles of soft sawdust. One afternoon, Michael and his friends climbed up to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge and looked at the lake. 

Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down!" He jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust. He laughed and shouted, "I dare you all! You're all cowards!" His friends looked scared but then one by one, they jumped down too. They all laughed and lay on the sawdust, telling jokes.

After a while, one friend said, "Let’s go up to the roof again and jump down." They were not very excited, but they went up. They jumped off, but Michael stayed on the roof. His friends called, "Come on, Mike! What’s wrong?" 

Michael wanted to jump, but he felt scared. He looked down at the ground and thought about jumping. His friends laughed at him because he was taking too long. They started to walk away, still shouting at him. 

Michael felt sad and alone. He stayed on the roof for a long time, watching the sun go down. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped down into the sawdust. He lay there for a while, and the yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. 

When he got up, he felt ashamed and walked home slowly. He was late for dinner. His stepmother said, "You should be home on time. If not, you can stay out tonight." She looked serious, but Michael didn’t really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change but don’t know how? Kitty Doherty has some good advice. Many people who want a new job go to a careers adviser. 

First, you write a short history about yourself. Then, you take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with suggestions for jobs and any training you might need.

I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. Taking the test felt like being in a science exam. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I had to remember that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard. They included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. 

After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was sad to learn I did not do well in the science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse! But it was good to hear I made the right choice in journalism.

Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. She said, "Losing my job was a chance to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. "I did not know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of training in design," she said. 

Donna also got other ideas, like taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she used her skills and found a job as a Public Relations officer. She said, "I think I would have found this job without Career Analysts, but they helped me see what I really wanted to do. I have sent six friends there, and they are all happy."

Some people feel they really needed help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services after working at a bank for six years. She said, "My job was boring, and I wanted a new challenge. I did not know what to do, so I went to the adviser with an open mind." 

She took the tests, which showed she liked sciences. She had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped her remember what she said. After the fourth meeting, she decided to study geology. She said, "The advice was worth the money. I am much happier now."

But not everyone finds careers advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, 24, was a sales representative. She said, "I did not know where to go in my career. I thought a careers adviser might help me. I got many new ideas, but I did not like them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of training. I did not learn anything new about myself. If I told a friend my story, they would give me the same advice."

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Many people only go to the dentist when they are in pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make the office a place where people feel safe. He does not wear a white coat because many people think white coats mean pain. He believes dental visits should be relaxing and fun.

Jerome uses new ideas to help people relax. One idea is virtual-reality headsets. His office was the first in Britain to use them, and many patients like them. When a patient sits on the blue couch, they can watch a movie about underwater animals while he checks their teeth. The headset also shows a special camera that lets the patient see inside their mouth.

The office smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today it smells like oranges. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. The usual dentist smell can make people scared. I thought the nice smell in the office was very good.

Jerome is known as a stylish dentist, but he takes his work seriously. The ways to help people relax are important, but good treatment is the most important. He uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a little strange, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental care. He found that when you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for the dentist too. He wants to change the way dentists work in Britain to make it less formal.

When a patient arrives, Jerome quickly goes to help. He offers them tea, asks what video they want to watch, and gently leads them to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a nice beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

**Chocolate: A Sweet Story**

Chocolate comes from South America. Now, it is a big business all over the world. In Britain, people spend a lot of money on chocolate at Easter. They buy more chocolate at Easter than at any other time, except Christmas.

A long time ago, the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans grew cacao plants in Central America. The cacao tree is a tropical plant. It grows in places like Africa and South America. The tree has big fruit that has 20 to 40 seeds inside. When the seeds are dried, they are called cacao beans. In English, they are often called cocoa beans. 

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water." This drink was special and used for ceremonies. The Spanish liked to add sugar and cinnamon to the drink. It took a long time for this drink to become popular in Europe.

In the late 1600s, people in Europe started to drink chocolate in special places called chocolate houses. For many years, people made chocolate drinks from solid chocolate. In 1826, a man named CJ van Houten made chocolate powder. This made it easier to make chocolate drinks.

In 1847, a company in Bristol made the first chocolate bar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate. At first, French companies sold most of the chocolate in Britain. But then, Cadbury made a famous chocolate bar called Dairy Milk in 1905. This bar became very popular.

Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies are always trying to find new ways to sell chocolate. They make chocolate bars into ice cream or desserts to attract more customers.

However, cacao farmers have had a hard time. In the late 1980s, the price of cocoa beans fell a lot. Many small farmers could not keep their farms. So, when you eat chocolate, remember the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He is very good at making art. He wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he is happy making beautiful things from shells. 

Peter shows me his work in his home. He asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring. He is interesting and his art is beautiful. He shows me some shell decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them. I love them." He never planned to sell his art. Five years ago, some friends told him to have an exhibition. They wanted people to see his work. They talked to a gallery owner. 

His first exhibition was in London, and 70% of his art was sold. His second exhibition just opened. The prices for his art are high. Some pieces cost around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a vase. Peter says he does not set the prices. He believes his work is special. 

Peter wishes he had started making art earlier. He thinks he could have made even better things. Now, he feels he cannot work as much because he is older. But his work is very different from the common shell art you see in shops. He makes boxes with many tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of beautiful flowers. 

Peter has his own way of working. He uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from shirts for his flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens." His work looks very nice and not random.

Peter travels to find beautiful shells. He has been to many places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He looks for shells on the beach. He only collects dead shells. He does not take shells with living creatures. He says, "I see many people breaking shells. I collect the ones that are left." 

Peter’s art is beautiful, and he believes it is okay to collect shells that are not alive.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. 

One day, a reporter named Jane Laidlaw is waiting to meet Kira. The receptionist says Kira will be late. Jane worries. She thinks about bad things she has heard about models. She wonders if Kira will come at all. 

But when Kira arrives, she is smiling and friendly. She is tall and pretty, wearing a simple black dress and trainers. Kira has to bring her mother with her because she is under 16. Kira's mother is proud of her daughter.

Kira did not plan to be a model. Her older sister told her to join a model competition. Kira said no, but her sister sent in some photos. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. She felt happy and confident. Kira won the competition and got a job offer from a model agency in London.

Now, Kira has two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school say mean things. They think Kira is too proud. Kira says she is still the same person, but she feels more confident now.

Being a model is busy. The agency can call her anytime for a job. Kira cannot always make plans with her friends because she does not know her schedule. But her friends understand and support her.

Kira has a bright future as a model. She is successful even before finishing school. When Jane asks Kira what she would do if she were not a model, Kira says, "I would like to do what you are doing."

**Father and Son Search for Gold**

Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son from Canada. They are looking for gold in Africa and Wales. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold, maybe 10,000 ounces. After ten years of digging, they believe they are very close to finding gold worth five million dollars.

Terence, who is 68 years old, said, "We are finding a lot of gold. We just need to dig a little more." They have worked hard to find gold. They started their search after Terence read about gold in a place called the Dolgellau gold belt in Wales. 

They read old mining books and chose a good place to dig. They cleared the land, found some gold in the rocks, and spent ten years getting permission to work. They took samples of the earth and removed old cars and trash. They dug out a lot of rock to make a tunnel.

Now, they need more money. They spent their savings and need £50,000 to dig deeper for the gold. Chris said it is hard to find a backer for the money. 

People in the area are interested in their search. Peter Woolven, who manages a hotel, said, "If they find gold, it could bring more tourists here." But he hopes many people do not come to dig in the hills.

The gold industry in Wales is not as strong as it was in the late 1800s when many people worked in mines. One mine that made wedding rings for the Queen closed last month. Now, more people are looking for gold again. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on a nearby hill. He said, "Searching for gold is exciting. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She teaches at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.

When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is like a small car. It takes her three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots who drive the vehicle. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside.

A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rocks and water, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.

The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. She was on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot got sick. They wanted to see how she would feel in a small space.

Now Rachel has dived six times. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The volcanoes blow out black smoke. The Russian team was leaving equipment to study a project that would make a hole in a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. They release water that looks like black smoke. This water comes out very fast and is very hot.

Rachel was scared the first time she dived with an American team. They were using equipment when there was a loud explosion. She thought she might die. They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was amazing!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the window, she sees the volcanoes. She feels wonder because no one else has seen them before. She studied black smokers for three years. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little tan. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. I was very tired. I could not understand any more train times, money, or languages. I said, "Never again," when I got home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. 

I just had to buy one train ticket. Because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. It rocks you to sleep. Carrying my things in a backpack made me travel simply. I learned to throw away things I did not need, like old socks and books. 

This way of traveling is part of Inter-Rail. You can forget about rules and just enjoy. All you need is a ticket. This ticket lets young people travel to many countries in one day. 

On my first trip, my friends and I did not know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra travel did not cost us anything. 

We were not only interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents. We made our own plans and only saw the sights that were easy to find. We wanted to do something different. I was proud that sometimes I only looked at the view from the train station. 

We just wanted to enjoy our time. We shared the train floor, food, water, money, and music with other travelers. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place you only heard about before. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. 

You can only understand Europe by seeing it. You see different places and lifestyles. Everyone knows about Europe, but it is not real until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a special experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this, even if it takes time.

Text: 

It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your bags are not there. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you may be in a very different place and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather.

Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes. It is hard for any airline to promise that your checked bags will go on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Airlines ask passengers to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for bags to be checked and put on the plane. There is also a minimum time needed to change flights. This time is often longer to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause delays. This can lead to lost bags.

Human mistakes can also happen, like if a bag label gets torn off. Big airports, called 'hubs', can have more problems because they handle many bags. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, and many were changing planes. British Airways had two million passengers changing planes there.

Even good airports like Amsterdam and Singapore can have bad days. Some airports, like Miami in the United States, are known for losing bags when passengers change planes quickly.

To avoid losing your bags, try to book direct flights. Check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline. Take an earlier flight to give yourself more time to change planes. Make sure to label your bags with your name and address inside and outside. Include your flight numbers too.

If your bags are still missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report before you leave the airport.

**The Kingfisher**

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer. He knows a lot about the kingfisher. The kingfisher is a small bird that is blue and green. It lives near rivers and streams and eats fish. 

Old trees grow near the water. The trees make some shade on the shallow water. The colors around are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sun. The kingfisher moves quickly and looks like a flash of light. It is very fast and can be hard to see. 

Charlie loved kingfishers when he was young. He does not know why he loves them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. One story says a goddess turned into a kingfisher. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its body became blue like the sky. 

Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. They look blue because of how their feathers are made. The light makes them look blue or green depending on the angle. 

Many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. They are shy but can be watched from a hiding place. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket over his head. He waited near a place where kingfishers liked to go. The bird came back very quickly and sat close to him. 

Charlie spent a lot of time by a stream with kingfishers. But he missed school because he wanted to be with the birds. He did not do well in school. At 16, he started working for a nature magazine. Later, he became a freelance wildlife cameraman. 

Now, Charlie wants to make a special film about kingfishers. He wants to show beautiful images without talking. He loves to take pictures of the kingfisher's wings. 

Charlie has spent many years with kingfishers. He feels a strong connection to them, and his photos show some of his feelings. But he knows there is much more to his love for kingfishers than what his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She wanted to learn from a famous conductor named Claudio Abbado in Vienna. One day, she had to help because an assistant was not there.
