After that, she helped with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. I was not nervous. I like standing in front of an orchestra," she said. Anne is from America and works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting good chances to work. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying two times before. He is happy it happened when it did. "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten," he said. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. But he worries about being known only for the competition. "If in three years people still think of me as a competition winner, I will be worried," he said. But now, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra invite him back to work.

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She loves the long practice time for opera. "The music needs four weeks of work," she said. She began conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional two years ago. Learning from Sian Edwards was important for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from bigger people," she said. She enjoys the complex nature of opera with its many arguments and different singers.

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He says conducting surprised him, but he finds it very interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed a show called Handel's Agrippina from the piano. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and tried my best," he said. He is thankful for all his experiences in music. Now, he is open to trying new things to find out what he enjoys.

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. In 1986, a famous conductor named Simon Rattle noticed him and told his agent about Wayne. Soon, Wayne had to conduct a musical in London with little notice. It was a hard start. Some musicians were reading newspapers during the show. "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat," he said. He believes that many musicians do not need much advice from a conductor. "I am not afraid to say what I want," he said. Wayne has not studied conducting in school, but he is determined and knows what he likes.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. We asked five families to try some parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were surprised! The park is good for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for little kids, and they enjoyed it a lot. For older kids, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, we were tired, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having fun. The park could be more exciting, and the view was not great. But the staff were very helpful, and the park was clean and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we did not know what to expect. We thought Oscar was too young, but he loved it! He enjoyed the Mountain Train and liked Little Land, where there are small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We spent six hours there and were happy there were places to rest. The park looked nice, and the staff were friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The kids loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great show. We went on the Terror Line, and the girls were scared but said they liked it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small for it! The park is well designed, and even waiting for rides is not boring. It is very clean, and the staff are nice. One staff member helped me with one of the girls when I could not sit with both.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**  
We got to the park at one o'clock and were sad it closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am scared of rides, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then becomes exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I did not want to go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun. If the children were older, they might think it was too easy, but they loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we felt that was true. The tallest roller-coaster in Europe, the Rocket, is very big. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters high, was worse! There are many rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff were nice to younger kids, but some were not very friendly. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We could not tell the kids we were going home early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside.

A. CHRISTINE HOGAN runs a computer design business. She says, "My customers are friends." She moved from London to the countryside with her husband when their children were small. She wanted to work from home. She had worked with computers before, so her husband suggested she start a computer design business. It was hard at first, and she needed a lot of money. She was careful with her spending and talked to the bank manager when she needed help. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evening if she wants. Her business is small, and people from the area come to pick up their work.

B. MAGGY SASANOW makes greeting cards from home. She says, "I enjoy being independent." She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different greeting cards to sell to museums. She works in a big room upstairs. Sometimes, it is hard to work from home because there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She does not advertise; people hear about her work by word of mouth. She is cheaper than other artists. Working alone can be lonely, but she likes it more than not.

C. DELIA TURNER makes curtains. She says, "It has been hard at times." She started her business eight years ago. At first, it was good, and her income grew a lot. She had six workers, but she had to let them go when the economy got worse. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. She sometimes has to lower her prices and look for new opportunities.

D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because it was cheaper than London, and she loves the country. She likes to work when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at different times. It is hard to stay focused and shut the office door. She publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because she had worked in London before.

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business and a shop. She started ten years ago at home. She is interested in health, so she makes fruit cakes with good ingredients. Friends and family asked her for cakes, and soon she was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building to make the cakes. Now, she has a baker and an assistant. She does not bake anymore; she manages the business. Her biggest problem has been money because she did not have a lot to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is very special. The sons are musicians and write music, and Dad makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins are teachers in South Wales. They have a ten-year-old son named Paul. Paul wanted a cello, but it was too expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one." He found a school where he could learn to make instruments. He took evening classes for three years.

After making some violins, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says it was very good. John made another cello for Paul, and he used it for many years. Now, John makes about twelve violins each year. He even sold one to a famous American musician.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul began with the piano. He loved to play it as soon as he could reach the keys. Later, he wanted to play the cello. His dad wanted him to play the violin, but Paul did not like it. He thought the cellist in his dad's group was very cool, so he took cello lessons.

Huw, now 22, also plays music. He is a pianist and composer. He says his parents were very supportive and did not push him too hard. 

Paul has done very well with the cello his dad made. He won a big music competition and became the main cellist for the BBC Symphony Orchestra when he was just 20 years old. Now, he plays a very old cello on loan from a music school. 

Paul will soon play on television, but he cannot watch it because he has a concert the same night. Huw also has a concert that night. Their parents, John and Hetty, will be very busy trying to see both of their sons perform.

**Looking after the Countryside**

**The National Trust**

The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the countryside in Britain. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust.

Gareth says a National Trust Warden needs common sense. He also needs to be good with people because he talks to farmers, visitors, and builders all the time. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. Many people wanted to be a warden, but Gareth got the job because he knows the area well and has farming experience.

Gareth still helps on his parents' farm. This helps him understand the farmers' problems. He can also do the hard work of the job, like building fences and planting trees. Since he started working for the Trust, he has learned more about nature. When he was young, he liked to pick flowers and collect butterflies. Now, he sees that farming has changed the countryside.

At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted different things. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth says they are close to working together.

Gareth's job includes helping people visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. He wants to finish jobs well and save money. He enjoys seeing projects done, but he also spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, even if he is always working. He likes talking to people, but some visitors can be rude. They come in, ask for everything, and leave without thanks. This can be frustrating for him. But Gareth believes that common sense is important.

If you have common sense and want to work outside, you might think about becoming a warden like Gareth. But remember, there may not be a job available in the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park.

I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She said, "I am focused on my training. I don’t see much else. I might see cars slow down, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My life is about being my best for the World Championships." She has a strict schedule to be very fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championship, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries playing.

Kendra said, "We will have support from home, which is special. It is important to make netball better in this country. There will be more pressure because people expect us to do well."

Their first game is against Barbados right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said, "We have always won against them, but they are good players."

The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra said the Championships will be hard. "You must play your best every day. There is no rest between games. You only have one chance to win."

In the fifteen years she has played, netball has become harder and faster. Kendra said, "You train to win. But after the game, we are friends."

Netball is also using more science to test fitness. Kendra said, "We must think and train like top players. As captain, I want to be strong and help my team."

Kendra said, "I have planned my netball career carefully. I decided that this competition will be my last as a player." She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. When she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

What can you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents do not see their child's talent until the child gets upset or acts out. Most regular schools help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special help. This help is not always available in regular schools, especially if music is not very important there.

Children who are very good at music can go to special music schools. There are five of these schools in Britain. They help children aged seven to eighteen learn music with professional musicians. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have lessons, practice in special rooms, and play in groups. They also study important subjects like English, math, and science, but less time is spent on these subjects compared to music.

The five music schools in Britain are independent. This means they are not part of the government school system. The classes are small, so teachers can pay more attention to each student. Most children live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be with other children who love music too.

However, there are some problems. The schools are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for children who live there. The schools try to help families with scholarships, which are financial aids. Also, not all parents want to send their young children to live at school. The directors of the schools worry about admitting very young children because it can be a lot of pressure. They want to help children grow up to be well-rounded people.

Sometimes, being in a special music school can be stressful. A child’s musical talent might change as they grow older. The pressure to succeed can make them feel like they are failing. The schools watch each child closely and offer help when needed. Many former students say they learned a lot from the music schools, but some wish they had more academic classes. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more in school.

It might be better to wait until a child is older to decide if they should go to a special music school. Children who are good at both music and school subjects can do well in regular schools with good music programs. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges. However, this option may not be available for families who live far from big cities.

**Artist Susan Shepherd and Her Garden**

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her garden is very big and has many flowers. She loves tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. 

The garden has two long flower areas next to a path. This path goes from one side to the other. The people who lived there before Susan took care of the garden. They left many plants that Susan likes. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas. But when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She does not paint the whole garden at once. She takes a flower to her studio and paints it. This can take a few days. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. 

Spring and early summer are busy times for Susan. This is when the tulips and poppies bloom. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." She also likes to see how flowers change. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She thought wild flowers were special because they grow in hard places, like rocks.

Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely. 

Susan is busy preparing for two art shows. She has a lot of flowers to paint, but she also knows that to understand her flowers, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex, England. This is her second year working in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

Sarah studied French and History of Art at university. She says being a chalet girl is not a long-term job, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two. She meets many interesting people.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.

After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She thinks cleaning is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. On good days, she skis until 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like to see a messy kitchen in the morning. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they want to be alone. 

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They visit different places to have fun. But on Saturday nights, she does not stay out too late because Sunday is her busiest day.

On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for the guests is at 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., she is ready for the new guests. They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. Then it is time for dinner again. Sometimes she talks with friends, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. One day, she went to the magazine Marie Claire. She said, "Choosing my clothes was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo." She went to a photo studio and then to meetings before lunch. The zoo is calm and quiet, but at the magazine, she was busy. Some people at the magazine looked stressed, but her job at the zoo is not stressful. In the afternoon, she laughed because she usually cleans animal cages. She likes how magazines work, but she loves her job at the zoo.

Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at the zoo. She wore leather boots and dark blue pants. The zoo gave her a green shirt to wear because she got very dirty. While she petted an elephant, she thought about Mandie working at the magazine. By five o'clock, she was dirty but happy. She said, "When I stop working in fashion, I might work with elephants in Africa."

Karen Hodson is a nurse. She worked with the TV show Ground Force. She was very excited to meet the team and the presenter, Alan Titchmarsh. She liked being outside because she sometimes does not see the sun at work. It was hard work, but she had fun. She thought she was strong, but the team was stronger. She realized that gardening is hard work, so she will keep her nursing job.

Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on Ground Force. He worked a day at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and gave out medicine. He thought he would feel faint, but he was okay. He liked the friendship among the nurses. He felt that his job is not as important as nursing. His day at the hospital was not easy, but he felt good about helping.

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She worked with Ryanair as cabin crew. She changed into the uniform and felt different. Before the flight, her boss talked about safety. When the passengers got on the flight to Paris, she gave out magazines. Everyone looked at her, and she felt shy. On the way back, there were 80 schoolchildren who were very noisy. She wished she was back at the gym with one adult to help.

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She worked as a personal trainer for a day. She was nervous because she does not exercise. She was surprised at how much attention trainers give to one person. In her job, she meets many passengers every day. At lunch, she saw that some trainers did not eat very healthy food, but they drank a lot of water. She does not want to change jobs, but she wants to join a gym and be healthier.

**On the Train**

Five famous people share their favorite memories of train journeys with Andrew Morgan.

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France. I go there as often as I can. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast to Italy. The views are beautiful, no matter the weather. You can see nice houses and gardens. The people on the train are fun. There are tourists and locals, all enjoying the trip.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have taken many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to Kruger National Park because I was too young. When I moved to England, I saw my first big train station, London Waterloo. It was amazing!

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
One special train for me is the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon in France. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress. I loved it! Someone said pink is good for the brain, so I wear it a lot now. The journey was lovely, and we took a boat on the Nile after that.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
I worked on a project about traveling around the world. We had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not good, and we had to wait. When the train came, many people got on, even on the roof! At night, we saw beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Many people love trains from when they are kids, but I did not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where there were not many trains. I started to love trains as a teenager when I made a film in Yorkshire. We filmed on an old train line. I loved riding the train, and when I went back last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights!

Text: 'Do you want to get your story published? Margaret Stubbs can help you. Many readers ask, "I wrote a story/book. Who should I send it to?" First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. To sell your writing, you must know about the market. 

One good way to learn is to read a lot. Go to your local library and visit bookshops. Reading helps you understand what publishers want. Remember, things change. New magazines and books come out all the time. 

If you want to write short love stories, find magazines that publish them. Get recent copies and see what kind of stories they like. Each magazine has different readers, and they want different things. 

Sometimes, new writers send their stories to me and ask, "This was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I try to be honest but positive. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you only have one story, it is hard to get published. 

When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have worked in writing for a long time. When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories. Write ten or twenty more. Each story will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. 

Don’t throw your stories away; make them better. At first, don’t show your work to others. Remember, many successful writers were rejected many times before they succeeded. 

Do everything you can to improve as a writer. Look for a creative writing class near you. If you can’t find one, join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and feel more confident. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

**No Title**

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were many more people than I thought. The station did not feel nice and clean like before. Old couples with matching bags sat on the benches, and college kids had their bags all over the floor.

A man with grey hair was walking around. He looked rich. He had nice clothes. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. She said no, she was going to New York. Then he asked a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I wanted to talk to her too. The man asked her, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said she was going north, but not to Philadelphia.

Next, he asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going to Wilmington. He kept walking. I was curious about him. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me, but he didn’t. He looked at me quickly and then walked away.

He looked worried. He asked a woman reading a book, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said yes. He asked her for a favor. I stood a little away and looked at my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. The woman seemed nervous. The man said, "It’s not too hard, I promise!"

They announced my train. People started moving to Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man told the woman, "My daughter is flying out today from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning and went home. My wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station and didn’t know what to do."

The woman felt sorry for him. I thought he should be quiet and let her ask questions. He said, "I told her to stay at the station. I will get someone to bring her passport."

I thought, "Why doesn’t he go himself?" The woman asked him, "Why don’t you go yourself?" He said, "I can’t leave my wife alone. She is in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. 

I looked at them. The man was holding a padded envelope, not a normal one. It was big like a book. I thought, "Be careful, lady!"

**Gary and Me**

John Moore is a restaurant owner. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant.

When John heard about the restaurant, he went to see it. The place was very old and needed a lot of work. But John thought it was perfect for him. This made him remember his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and John felt sad when he was alone. He wanted to have time for his family.

John's wife took care of the children and helped with the money. John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This was good for their children, Gary and Joe. They became very confident. When they were young, they talked to the customers.

Gary was a lively child. One time, when he was seven, he jumped into the bath and hurt himself. As he grew up, he did small jobs to earn pocket money. By ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend and had a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and woke up early.

Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he could cook as well as the adults. Sometimes, he was in charge and made over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would work in cooking.

When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant. Gary also started playing the drums and formed a band. John told Gary to focus on one thing, or he might not succeed in either.

John advised Gary to achieve his goals by age 30. If not, it might be too late. At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, he finished his work very quickly and even helped others. 

Now, Gary has a successful TV cooking show, and John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary to work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. John believes that if children listen to even a little of what you say, it is good. Gary has listened and done well.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is to know someone. If you know a person who knows someone else who is moving, that can help. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you do not know anyone. Jo had just arrived in Dublin. She had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown place. She felt nervous when she took the train to go there for work. She did not think about why she was going. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to go to new places and have a better life. Some of her friends went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo's mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because many hostels are cold. Jo's sisters, who worked in a hotel, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. But Jo did not know they were talking about her. She saw an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to her job at the post office and seemed perfect. Jo hoped it would be nice and not too expensive.

There was no line for this flat because it was looking for a third girl to share. The ad said "own television," and Jo worried it might be too fancy for her. The house looked normal, a red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf came down the stairs. She looked unhappy. "This place is bad," she told Jo. "The girls are not nice."

Jo kept going up the stairs. "Hello," said the girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I don’t like her." Jo asked what happened. Nessa said the girl acted silly and talked in a posh voice. "We don’t want her here," Nessa said.

Pauline, another girl, had bright clothes and hair. Jo thought she looked interesting. Jo introduced herself. "I work in the post office," she said. Nessa said they were going to have tea. She got three mugs. One had "Nessa," one had "Pauline," and the last one had "Other." "We can put your name on a mug if you stay with us," Nessa said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We like to see them in the sea, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds tells us about this problem.

Dolphins are very smart animals. They can feel human emotions and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. We see dolphins in shows like Flipper and Seaquest. But these happy shows do not show the real life of dolphins. The seas are dirty and full of fishing. 

Many dolphins are disappearing. In the North Sea, the number of harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down a lot. You might think that dolphins are protected by laws and live in safe places. This is not true. There are no good plans to help them, and this could be a big problem for wildlife.

There are forty types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, we can find striped dolphins, common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, and smaller harbour porpoises. Striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea. We do not see them often, and we do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are social and were often found in places like the Thames River in Britain. Now, we can only find them in a few places in Scotland and Wales. The dolphins that are left show signs of stress.

It is hard to know why dolphin numbers are going down. Overfishing is taking away their food. If fish are caught in one area, dolphins may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets that they cannot see. Many fishing methods use big nets that can hurt dolphins. In recent years, many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. They have marks and cuts from these nets.

Dolphins can also get sick from waste in the sea. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. When female dolphins have babies, their milk can have these poisons. There is a case of a baby dolphin that died from its mother’s milk.

Another big problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. Noise from ships and oil wells can disturb them. This noise travels better in water than in air, and we do not know how it affects dolphins yet.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind and body. It helps you feel good and stay healthy. Many people talk about fitness because it is really good for you. 

There are many reasons to exercise. It makes your muscles stronger and can change your body shape. It helps you stand and sit better. Exercise can also help you avoid injuries. It is good for your heart and lungs, and it helps your blood flow.

Exercise can help with feelings of sadness and tiredness. It can help you sleep better and reduce stress. It can also help with some health problems. 

There are many types of exercise you can do, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. But be careful! If you exercise too hard, you can get hurt. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are not sure what is good for you.

Good posture is very important. It helps you look and feel better. If you slouch, think of a balloon pulling you up. This can help you stand tall and breathe better. 

Stretching is also important. It helps your body move easily and prevents injuries. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will feel more flexible and fit. 

A good exercise routine should include warming up, stretching, a workout, and cooling down.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for a long time? They want to find the best shots of animals. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa, where it is hard to find them because they are always moving. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained a lot for six months. This has caused some problems. Owen said they had to buy a special tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud.

Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films, like their famous film about leopards. While people were watching this film, they were already looking for another shy animal, the jackal. Film-makers have traveled the world to film animals since television started.

I talked to Owen when he was at a safari lodge with other people. He said, "We sometimes argue, but we make up quickly." They do not see one person as the leader. They both understand animals in the same way. 

When they travel, they set up their tents each night. Now, they have a fixed camp. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before. They eat pre-packed meals that they heat up. Owen said, "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be stressful."

It can be tough, but being in nature helps them get close to the animals. Owen remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would go away and then come back to greet her family and even their car.

Owen first worked with Amanda in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Now, they spend four months in one place to get enough material for each film. Before they start, they must send a script for approval.

Owen said, "Amanda and I worked well together from the start because we have the same ideas. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals. We want to touch people's hearts. If we can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**

In this story about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is getting ready for the World Championships next month. She teaches at a local school and trains in a supermarket car park. Suzie asked her if people look at her when she trains there. Kendra said she is too focused on her training to notice.

Kendra said, "I want to be my best for the Championships." She has a strict schedule to be fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries playing. Kendra is happy to have support from fans in England. She wants to make netball better known in the country. There will be more pressure because they are playing at home. People expect them to do well.

Their first game is against Barbados right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said they usually win against them, but it will still be exciting to play. The England team is ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be hard. "You have to work hard every day. There is no rest between games," she said. "In the Championships, you only have one chance to win."

Kendra has played netball for fifteen years. The game is now faster and players are more aggressive. "We train hard to win," she said. But after the game, everyone is friendly.

Netball is also using more science to help players train. Kendra believes it is important to think and train like the best players. As captain, she wants to support and encourage her team.

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition will be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on this big event. When she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might cry because she knows her fans will support her.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She teaches at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.

When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is like a small car. It takes her three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.

The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. An instructor was with her. He told her what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot got sick. They wanted to see how she would feel in a small space.

Now, Rachel has dived six times. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was leaving some equipment to study the volcanoes.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. They release water that looks like black smoke. The water comes out very fast and is very hot.

The only time Rachel was scared was when she dived with an American team. They were using a long rope when there was a big explosion. Rachel thought she would die. They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was amazing!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the window, she sees the volcanoes. She feels wonder because no one else has seen them. Rachel studied black smokers for three years. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. People often decide what they think about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice.

Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard and graduated. She felt confident. She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she did not want to be late. She believed it was important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not look good at an interview, how can she be a good teacher?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that people who care about how they look are more likely to care about their jobs. Many people forget that looking professional is important. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big accounting firm. When her boss retired, she wanted the job but did not get an interview. She asked why and was told she did not look like an office manager. They suggested she change her clothes before applying again. Janet was surprised because she thought her work was good and her clothes should not matter.

How we move and use our hands can also affect what the interviewer thinks. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from the words we use. 38% comes from our voice, and 55% comes from our facial expressions. If our words and our face say different things, people will believe our face more. So, it is important that our words match our body language. Confusing messages can make the interviewer unsure.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went very well, and she was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how happy she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have asked for more money if she had been calmer.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us in an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, says it is good to learn about the company before the interview. Reading the company report can help. You can mention something interesting during the interview to show you care about the company. Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and using short sentences. She says, "Good communicators use short sentences. Poor communicators talk too much."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work in an office in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He thought it was fun at first, but then it became boring. One day, he lost his job. He did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start his farm. He met a chef from a hotel. He started selling meat to the hotel. Now, he also sells meat online. He is happy to be outside and not in an office, but he still works a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week.

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career helper who was surprised. Most people want to go back to work for money. But Ron and his wife had grown children, so they could try something new. They moved to the north of England where they did not know anyone. They miss their friends, but many come to visit them.

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her flat in London. She liked her job, but it was very busy. She did not want to work more hours, so she left. Some people thought she would get bored, but she did not. She has many deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier and less stressed now. She misses talking to other workers. She likes being in charge of her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her fault.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance when he was 22. He liked the excitement, but he did not feel happy. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to travel for a year. He wanted to find out what to do next. He liked health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He took courses in massage to learn. Now, he works part-time at the Life Centre. He is happy and feels in control of his life.

**Dedicated to Their Sports**

Four young sports stars talk about their lives.

**A Darius (runner)**  
I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. Many people did not notice, which was sad. I hoped to get some money for training, but it is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there, and I have to be very disciplined. If my friends want to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but I need to work hard. My big goal is to go to the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

**B Gabriel (surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. If I want to be good, I cannot go to late-night parties. I do not mind this, but I love to sleep in. I have to give that up too. But it is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out. If I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning helped me get a job on TV, so now I am a bit famous.

**C Dieter (yacht racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in a big way. Some people say we act like kids, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so I love to come back and hang out with my friends. You cannot only think about sports all the time; it is not healthy. People know me in sailing, but I am not famous. I get nice letters from fans who want my picture, and I reply to every one.

**D Tomas (tennis player)**  
It feels great to walk on the court and hear the crowd cheer for me. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many people around. I like when fans see me when I am out shopping. But it can be hard too. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in sports. I focus on my game now and will think about other things in life when I retire, which is early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "My kids want everything they see. If it’s not a new sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three! I can’t buy everything. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it’s not good for them. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This makes it hard for parents to explain why they cannot buy certain things. Children do not always understand why their parents say no, especially when they see fun ads on TV.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat. They want to give them healthy food, but they do not always know what is healthy. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel stressed because they have to say no to their children often."

The rules for TV ads say that advertisers cannot tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Susan Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy things. So, even if they do not say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."

Shopping with children can be tiring for parents. One mother says she talks to her son about food and ads. She feels happy that he does not ask for things she does not want to buy. 

Some parents admit they are not always fair. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets for our son because they are bad for him, but we buy treats for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and children want to enjoy that too. But sometimes, I get annoyed with their requests. If I am in a good mood, I might say yes more often. It is hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help parents by moving sweets away from the checkout area or by having play areas for children. Even if parents spend less money without their children, many would still come to shop if they did not have to deal with their kids' requests.

Text: 'The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology to help both guests and staff. 

The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know the guests' names. He uses a computer system to remember what guests like. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. It cost a lot of money to set up, but it will help the hotel save money in the future. 

For example, if a guest asks for certain music during their first stay, the hotel will have that music ready for them when they come back. 

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can set it between 14°C and 25°C. 

The hotel also has special technology for business guests. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel is ready for new technology by adding extra cables and renting televisions. This way, they can change to newer models easily. 

The hotel has 145 comfortable and welcoming rooms. There is a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. 

The food is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. He has made a new kitchen that is modern and better than before. 

With great food, good technology, and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.'

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann** (Journalist and author): "I get energy from excitement. I like challenges and learning new things. Dancing gives me energy too. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. If I am bored, I feel tired. Doing something useful, even a little, makes me feel good."

B. **Linda Kelsey** (Magazine editor): "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I love my job. If you like what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need sleep to feel good. I try to sleep enough. Exercise helps me feel energetic, but I need to find the energy to do it! I do yoga once a week and some workouts at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. In the afternoon, I often feel low, so I try to eat something then."

C. **Annie Nightingale** (Disc jockey): "I don’t eat healthy food for energy. I think being positive gives me energy. I don’t like negative people. I believe we should enjoy life. I love my job and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many young and lively people. I like taking photos and writing fun song lyrics when I travel."

D. **Floella Benjamin** (Author and children's TV presenter): "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and being positive helps. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Smiling at people makes me feel good. I try to eat healthy food and I don’t smoke or drink. I get energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach** (Author and playwright): "I love making gardens from empty land. I once turned a concrete area into a garden. It was better than any exercise. I also get energy from knowing people want to read my writing. I like exploring nature, even if it is private land. It feels fun and childlike."

F. **Katherine Monblot** (Therapist): "You need to care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and I get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don’t want to do makes you tired. I used to be on many committees, but I didn’t like it. You have a limited amount of energy, so use it for what is important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating is a fun activity that people have done for many years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. Later, they started using iron skates. In Scandinavia, skating was important for rich people. 

In the early 1900s, skating became popular. A young girl named Sonja Henie showed a new way to skate at the 1924 Winter Olympics. Now, skating is both beautiful and hard work. 

If you want to learn to skate, you need to balance and control your body. To balance, keep your legs slightly bent and lean a little forward. Relaxing is very important when you skate. 

To start skating, put your heels close together and turn your feet out. Push with your back foot and move the other foot a little. It is easy! As you practice, you can make bigger movements. 

Learning how to fall is also important. Even good skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, stay relaxed. This helps you not get hurt. To get up, use your hands to kneel and then stand up. 

Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, and speed skating. It is best to start with figure skating. Many ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn. 

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To skate well, you should practice exercises for your legs, back, and shoulders. Warm-up exercises are important to avoid getting hurt. 

Skating helps you balance, move better, and stay healthy. It is good for your heart and lungs. When you skate with swimming or jogging, it helps you stay fit and strong.

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a child win a medal can make you very happy. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.

A. Annika Reeder is 15 years old. She won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the Olympics. "I work very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV or go out with friends. I focus on gymnastics and school. Sometimes I feel very tired, and my coach gives me a day off, but usually, I keep training. If I take too many days off, I get stiff."

B. Annika's mother says, "Annika has always been very talented. Some parents push their children too much, but Annika wants to do this. It takes a lot of time and energy. People say we give up a lot, but we love the sport and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy, but now she is confident and has friends from all over the world."

C. Sarah Stokes is 10 years old. She started show-jumping when she was 10 and has won the British National Championship. "My parents love show-jumping. They train me and take me everywhere. The shows can last from one to five days. I love it! I want to qualify for the British young riders team and win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. Sarah's mother says, "Sarah loved horses from a young age. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To compete, we travel all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is very happy on a horse and knows what to do. It is wonderful to see your child succeed at something they love."

E. Jane McShane is 10 years old and is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone and it is fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t want to feel embarrassed."

F. Jane's mother says, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. Jane loved chess right away. By 6, she was beating adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wants to stop playing, I will support her. I want her to use her talent and be the best she can be."

Text: 

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already very tall. Now, he is the tallest man in Britain at 228 cm.

Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were a long time ago. We are getting better food now, which helps us grow taller.

A scientist named Professor Chris Stringer says we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different foods. Women picked fruits and herbs, and men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants.

About 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed how people ate. Now, most people eat mainly three plants: wheat, rice, and maize. This diet is not very good for health. Many people became sick and underweight when they started farming. In Ohio, scientists found that healthy hunters became sick farmers when they grew corn.

Farming spread because it could feed more people. But many people still do not get enough good food. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets getting better again. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Even though people are getting taller, some things have not changed. Beds are still 190 cm long since 1860. There is less space for legs in planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often.

Scientists wonder how tall people will get. They think we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. But there is a problem. While some people are getting taller because of better food, as a group, humans are getting smaller. A long time ago, during the ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we are getting thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might get even smaller.

**Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"

Some people think studio audiences are not important. They say that even TV workers do not care about them. I thought studio audiences were just made up of silly people who want to be on TV. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different jobs and backgrounds. TV shows want different types of people to watch.

Many people at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for a long time just to watch TV? One reason is that people hope to be on TV for a moment. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came for a chance to be on TV."

Another reason is that people want to see how a show is made. But many people go because a friend gave them a ticket. Most of us have not been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers, and someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH. You clap or laugh when you see these signs. This is true for some shows, but not all.

One studio manager said, "We think a show should be good enough not to need these signs." But is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch at home, you miss a lot."

What I missed was seeing the actors live. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were far from where I sat, so I ended up watching the show on a monitor. Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but for most people, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I do not like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to the village of Lastingham. Cycling was fun and helped me relax. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also new. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. This was my first travel writing.

**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. It is run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive. The view is not amazing. The train goes over fields with sheep and next to a canal. But I love one part of the journey. The train goes through back gardens. For a moment, I can see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding chairs. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and the sea. It makes me look closer and find new things.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. Some surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and has many shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast and into beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple place with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open area perfect for hiking. There are not many people living or visiting there. It is quiet and empty, and I like the space. I found this place by chance when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, sometimes with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but I went to school in Devon, England, when I was twelve. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you would never come back. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We love animals and enjoy having them around. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She found a pine snake and asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals like this. 

I got home late and started to boil some water. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. The problem was with our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca. Bianca was a gift for Mother's Day. 

Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth. He wanted to escape with it. I jumped into the room and tripped over something. I fell on the floor. I saw the snake escaping from the table and onto the floor. 

The snake was moving fast, and the kids were jumping around, screaming. The dog was barking. The pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and went back to help. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse from him. 

I looked at the snake. It seemed strong and I was worried. I sat on the floor and tried to calm the snake. Slowly, it relaxed and rested its head on its body. I carefully lifted the snake and walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to let it go near a tree. 

When I let go of the snake, it surprised me. Instead of running away, it climbed up on my shoulders like a warm scarf. My four children and I stood together with the snake. My oldest son, DJ, said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not." 

I asked the kids to help me encourage the snake to move. Slowly, it went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the snake went away, my three-year-old son, Clay, said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**

In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is becoming rare. But I love getting letters. There is a special joy in seeing a letter arrive, finding out who it is from, and reading what it says.

I have written letters for a long time. I started by writing little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I was 18, I moved to London to study to be a doctor. I wrote to my mother every week, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote to me too, and I loved his funny letters. Most of the letters from home were about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.

I also got letters from my boyfriends. They had to work or study far away, so we wrote to each other. Writing letters helped our relationships. I found it easier to say what I felt in a letter than in person.

I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but I love getting news from a whole year! It is even better when the letter comes in airmail with pretty stamps. I get letters from friends in other countries, like Sri Lanka, Australia, and Canada. I also have a friend in France. We started talking in a restaurant, and I asked for her address. Now we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her, and we have visited each other.

This summer, my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that we wrote for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about us!

I am happy that my children are also writing letters. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas too.

I hope everyone keeps writing letters. It is a special way to connect with others!

**Careless Tourists Hurt Old Rock Art**

Many old pictures on rocks in France are being damaged. There are 36,000 drawings in Mont Bego, a famous place in the French Alps. These drawings are very old, about 4,000 years. They show cows, fields, and gods. 

More and more people visit this place, but some do not take care of the drawings. Jean Clottes, a leader in rock art, says that if people keep damaging the drawings, they will be gone in 50 years. He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and hurting them. Some people even take pieces of the rocks home. Others rub the drawings to take better photos. 

Some visitors bring sticks to scratch their names on the rocks. Experts have different ideas on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, a museum director, thinks the best way is to close the mountain to the public, except for guided tours. He believes this will help save the site. 

But Jean Clottes thinks this idea is too strict. He says it will make local people unhappy. David Lavergne, an architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says it is hard to stop visitors from damaging the area because there are not enough guards. They might need to charge money to visit the site.

Annie Echassoux, who studies the site, is worried that more tourists will come because it is easier to reach now. She believes they should block off some areas and have guides. She says it is important to find money to protect the drawings because they are a historic site. If they do not act, future generations will lose these important drawings.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "My kids want everything they see. If it’s not a new sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three! I cannot buy all these things. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it is not good for them. But I also feel bad when I say no all the time. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to make choices."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on advertising for children, mostly on TV. This makes it hard for parents because children do not understand why they cannot have everything. Parents want to give their children healthy food, but children see many ads that make unhealthy food look good.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat. They want to teach them about healthy food. But if children only see ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents feel bad because they have to say no to their children because of ads."

The rules for TV ads say that advertisers cannot tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Susan Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy things. So, even if they do not say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is what they want."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents. One mother says she talks to her children about food and ads. She feels happy because her son does not ask for things she does not want to buy. 

Some parents are not always fair with their children. Mike, a father, says, "We do not buy sweets for our son because we say they are bad for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and children want to share that. But sometimes, I get annoyed with their requests. If I feel good, I say yes more often. It is hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets can help parents by moving sweets away from the checkout area or by having play areas for children. Even if parents buy less when their children are not with them, many would enjoy shopping without their children's demands.

**Going Up the Wall**

Climbers used to go to the mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. The crowd is quiet. High on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is in a big climbing competition in Birmingham.

The place is called the National Indoor Arena. It is known for the TV show Gladiators, but it also has climbing competitions. This is possible because of new technology.

Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit. When they could not use cliffs, they climbed on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and not get bored.

Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls. These walls had special bricks to hold on to. A teacher named Don Robinson built a climbing wall in a hallway at Leeds University in the 1960s. He put natural rock in concrete to make climbing walls.

In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built, but they had problems. The walls were straight up, but cliffs have different shapes. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed. Climbers got tired of the same holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material. He made shapes like those on cliffs. These shapes could be put on any wall and taken off when climbers wanted something new. French companies also made climbing walls with steel frames. Steel was lighter than concrete, so they could build overhanging walls easily. This gave climbers many new holds to try.

Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone this, they might say it is risky. Acting can be a risky job. There are many actors, but not many jobs for them. When you decide to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy. But everyone has different opinions. It is your choice, and you are responsible for it. 

There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take tests, but there is no guarantee you will get a job after training. Success depends on luck and talent. People want new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.

What is talent? Talent is a natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on a person’s courage and belief in what they do. 

Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important thing is the moment between the actor and the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to perform.

Actors often do not know how they succeed. They understand some things about themselves and their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they can be out of work one month and then get a chance to audition the next. 

Actors do not like to talk about their chances of getting a job. They find ways to deal with the stress of competition and rejection. No one likes to be rejected. From the start, when you want to be an actor, you say you are ready and talented. But if you do not care enough, others will not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**

We have a special selection of the best cookbooks for you. 

A. When you think of a famous TV cook, you might think of Delia Smith. She has recipes from many places in the world. Her recipes are easy to follow and good for everyone. Her famous book is called "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book helps you learn to cook. It has many simple recipes that are fun to make. If you want one good cookbook, this is the one!

B. Raymond Blanc is a famous chef in Britain. He worked hard for 15 years to become a great chef. Now, he has a TV show called "Blanc Mange" and a book with the same name. In his book, he teaches us how to cook better. He explains how ingredients work together. He has over 80 great recipes. This book helps you understand cooking and why some dishes can go wrong. Raymond loves to cook for others, and he is very good at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a famous cooking school that teaches French cooking. For 100 years, they have trained many chefs. To celebrate their anniversary, they made a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook." This book has 100 classic recipes. The recipes are easy to follow and look delicious. The book starts with basic cooking tips and then has sections for starters, main dishes, and desserts. Chefs from around the world share their best recipes and secrets in this book.

D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, a food editor, thinks differently. His new book is called "The 30-Minute Cook." He believes you can make tasty food quickly. In this book, you will find recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel has written over 200 recipes from different countries. He shows that fast food can be good food. Try his recipes; they are delicious!
